text:
Very yummy. I think the variance in reviews between liking it and saying it is too sharp and vinegary could be due to the quality of balsamic vinegar used. Good quality balsamic is so mild you can eat it straight off a spoon and it is almost sweet. Inexpensive balsamic might as well be plain white vinegar. So don't be thrifty on the vinegar quality, you'll only regret it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night and it was awesome.  I made just a couple changes.  I used 1/4 cup balsamic and 1/4 white whine.  I also added a squeeze of honey and a clove of pressed garlic.  
After marinading, i put into a 9 x 13 baking dish and poured all the marinade in with it.  I put in one large chopped onion, 4 medium yukon gold potatoes cut up, 4 carrots cut in sticks and two stalks of celery cut up.  I layed them right down on top of the marinade in the pan and kind of mixed them around a bit to soak up the juices.  I then sprinkled with rosemary, salt and pepper.  I baked on 350 for 45 min in a foil tent, then cranked up the heat to 450 and took the foil tent off.  I cooked the roast for 10 min this way, then took out to rest & wrapped in foil.  Then I stired the veggies around in the juices and then put them back in the 450 oven for about 15 more minutes.  THIS WAS FANTASIC.  Everything had a wonderful glaze to it.  The meat was moist and oh so good.  :)  Thanks for the great starter recipe! :)

text:
I made this with a dusty (and I do mean covered in dust) old half-gone cheapity-cheap bottle of Cento balsamic vinegar that I've probably owned for 3 or 4 years.  Shameful, I know.  But I say all that to say that...WOW WOW WOW.  You probably don't have to worry too terribly much about the quality or price of the vinegar.  This was SO incredibly good.  And the whole house smelled fantastic while cooking.  And my 3, 4 and 8 year olds gobbled it down, also.  I followed the advice of another reviewer and cut two yellow onions into thick slices and lined the bottom of the baking dish with them.  This was absolutely the way to go.  Those onions were perfectly cooked, drenched in the yummy sauce, and my husband and I heaped them all over the meat.  Just writing this review makes me want to go back to Trader Joe's right now to get another roast...annnnd *maybe* a new bottle of balsamic vinegar.

text:
I love the taste of balsamic vinegar, so this recipe was right up my alley.  Added 3 crushed garlic cloves along with a little salt and pepper to the marinade - Perfect!

I have also noticed some discussion about the temperature to cook the meat.  On May 24, 2011 the USDA made some important changes in their recommended cooking temperatures for meats. Here’s what you need to know:

When Cooking Whole Cuts of Pork USDA has lowered the recommended safe cooking temperature for whole cuts of pork from 160 ºF to 145 ºF with the addition of a three-minute rest time. Cook pork, roasts, and chops to 145 ºF as measured with a food thermometer before removing meat from the heat source, with a three-minute rest time before carving or consuming. This will result in a product that is both safe and at its best quality—juicy and tender.

So anything above 145 ºF is safe after a 3 minute rest period.  Then it is just a matter of taste.  I use the following as a rule of thumb: 145 ºF yields a wonderfully juicy Medium Rare, 155 ºF produces a solid Medium Well and 165 ºF creates a dusty Well Done.  These temperatures are out of the oven temperatures and still need the rest period.

Thanks for a great tasting recipe.

text:
Have made this recipe many times now.  It always turns out great.  My husband tells me every time that its worthy of being served in a fine restaurant.  A little trick that I learned, is if you take the leftover marinade after the roast is cooked, strain out the seasoning, add 1/4 cup brown sugar and boil for a few minutes, you get a wonderful glaze to pour over the cut pieces. Truly a simple and wonderful recipe!

text:
Very tasty, and simple.  Just a note to the person that gave this a low review but did this in a slow cooker.  All slow cookers are not alike, and I think the word slow cooker can be deceiving.  I too have had things come out dry in the slow cooker, but usually from cooking to long to where you simply cook the moisture out of the meat. I think timing is so important in the slow cooker, and adding some chicken broth may help some.  Chicken broth and pork go great together.  I would try this recipe in the oven as it is posted here first, you might be pleasantly surprised.  I always follow a recipe to the letter, then make changes based on my likes and dislikes.

text:
Amazing! Oh the smell is to die for. I am a huge balsamic fan anyways. I have made this a few times and recommend a thermometer for sure. I didn't use one once and it ended up too dry. Now I cook it to 145 and pull it out. I also used a metal pan once because my only proper glass one was in use and the marinade burned to the bottom. SO USE GLASS. It doesn't burn in the glass pan. I use Weber Chicago steak seasoning. And I marinate it for about 10 hours. How could something so easy taste so wonderful! I like to make it with asparagus and I used the leftover marinade over it and the pork when I serve it. Sometimes I splash a bit more vinegar on mine, but that might not be for everyone. Like I said, I just love balsamic. My other half cant stand the smell or taste of vinegar but he is a fan of this pork.

text:
Hate to be the one who says it's great but changes everything, and yet...this is a great recipe, but I changed a few things, and it was truly gourmet.  I marinated as indicated (with my own dry rub), using organic golden balsamic vinegar: a great choice.  I then took a trick from prime rib and mixed 1/2 cup flour with some spices (herbamare, garlic, onion powder), and coated the roast with the flour mixture.  I then baked the roast at 450 for 15 minutes before lowering the temp for the rest of the cooking time.  This left a nice, crusty outer, and a lovely, juicy meat.  I used the scrapings from the pan and made a sauce by incorporating some homemade broth.  I also roasted some veggies (beets) along with the meat: it was great!

text:
I use a very similar marinade all the time. Same amounts of olive oil and balsamic vinegar but I add a couple Tbsp each of dijon mustard and honey, several sprigs of fresh thyme and 3 or 4 cloves of crushed and chopped garlic.  When I want to spice things up a bit I'll add a Tbsp of crushed red pepper plus juice and zest of 1 lime. I always marinate overnight and salt and pepper the meat before putting it in oven or on the grill.  I use this marinade for pork, chicken and even rib roasts. Don't be afraid to try this or to experiment and make it your own. Excellent marinade, thanks for sharing, Melissa.

text:
This was a great recipe. I always have trouble with my pork loin -it never seems to come out tender enough for my young toddler (15months old) to chew -so we eat tenderloin mostly. There was a sale on pork loin this week and I decided to try another pork loin and this recipe was amazing. 

I made some changes:
I used 1/4 cup white wine vinegar and 1/4 cup white balsamic vinegar (because we were out of my regular balsamic vinegar)
I also didn't have steak seasoning, but I found the ingredients list and so I added salt, pepper, garlic powder, paprika and rosemary. 
I marinated it all day and then roasted it that evening -it was so tender!! I could not believe this was my pork loin!! 
Because I used white balsamic vinegar I didn't need to add anything to make my drippings into a wonderful sauce for the pork! 

The only thing I had a problem with was the temperature. Pork cooks to 170 -175, not 145 as stated in the recipe. Even with standing and tenting, that would not be cooked enough. It took me about 1 3/4 hrs for my 3lb roast to cook and I had to jack the temp up to 375 after the first hour because I was running late by that time. I'm still giving it 5 stars though!

text:
The flavor was delicious, but as other reviewers have mentioned, the meat itself is a little tough.
Update: I take it all back. I've tried a few different variation on this recipe now. The meat was only tough when I let it marinate for only two hours. When you leave it overnight or even 2 nights it gets juicy, tender, and delicious. Also, carrots, butternut squash, sweet potatoes, and pretty much any sweet vegetable taste AMAZING roasting along with this dish in its sauce.

text:
I just had the most delicious roast pork loin thanks to this recipe!  My balsamic was a bit tart, so I corrected the flavor with a bit of honey to taste.  I roasted carrots and onions with the pork.  Yum!  Served with new potatoes sauteed in brown butter, steamed buttery hericots verts from the garden, and homemade wheat rolls, this was one memorable meal!

Thank you for posting the recipe.  This is so beautiful as a base marinade.  Many wonderful things can be added, or it can be great as is (with a sweetish balsamic).  Everyone just needs to taste the marinade before putting over the pork.  If your vinegar is too sharp, the marinade is easily corrected with a little honey or brown sugar.

text:
This is a great idea but has too much oil which doesn't reduce.  The second time I sliced my meat into 1 1/2 inch rounds and covered with my preferred salty steak rub for slightly more than an hour.  I learned in a cooking magazine that this is a form of brining.  At first the surface is very wet but the salt and liquid is drawn back into the meat.  I used only 1/4 cup of olive oil and the whole amount of vinegar and cooked for a shorter time to reach the correct temperature.

text:
FINALLY!!!  I'm a pretty decent cook but no matter what I do, I always and I repeat always overcook pork.  If it's undercooked and I throw it back in BAM it's overdone and bland.  This recipe was super easy, I actually had everything in my house already (including a pork rub I used instead of steak) and I did add sliced garlic to the mix.  I thought for sure it would be too heavy on the balsamic but it was amazing and although I cooked it a little long it was still super moist.  Usually left over pork gets tossed but we fought over the leftovers!  I also sauteed some mushrooms in a pan and added the cooked marinade (while the pork was resting) to the pan and a little flour to thicken it up and poured that over my finished product and it was incredible.  Thank you so much for this new staple to our meals.

text:
I made this for dinner last night & everyone loved it!  The only thing I did differently is I used pomegranate infused balsamic vinegar, added lots of chopped garlic and roasted baby carrots along side.  I also placed the roast, fat side up on top of sliced red onion.  This keeps the roast from sitting directly on the pan. It won't stick to the pan and the onion flavor is infused into the roast.  I also added a 1/4 cup of water to the pan while roasting. There was plenty of cooking liquid left to make a wonderful gravy!  I will definately make this again!  Thanks!

text:
Had a 4 lb pork loin, so I doubled the recipe. Added 1/3C honey, 2 cloves minced garlic & some minced green onion. After piercing meat all over with a fork, I marinated it for about 6 hours. Baked (with some sliced baby carrots) at 350 for 1 hour and 45 minutes. The meat was tender & the flavor was delicious! After baking, I mixed a cornstarch roux in with the leftover liquid...made a delicious sauce for the meat, carrots & mashed potatoes!

text:
One of the best recipes I've tried.  I always start with an organic pork loin.   Did add 1/4 cup honey and lots of garlic  some kosher salt and pepper to the marinade as others suggested and marinated over 2 hours.  Place in large cast iron skillet and surrounded with sweet potatos, yellow potatos, carrots and onions poured in marinade with a little dry white wine (one time I used organic chicken broth) and cooked on indirect heat for 2-3 hours to 145 degree.  Family loved it!!  First recipe in a long time that there where absolutely no leftovers.  Must try and do use a good balsamic vinegar as well as good quality olive oil.

This recipe was SOOO good!!!!! I loved it! I've had so much trouble with cooking pork loin before this recipe. It would always turn out dry!! This was the complete opposite. text:
This was delicious; my husband loved it, too.  I made it exactly as directed, and I used Emeril's Steak Rub.  It was a last minute decision, so I marinated the meat for only about 2 + 1/2 hours.  I wonder if the reviewers who complained of the flavor being too strong marinated overnight - balsamic is very powerful stuff and I think a longer marinating time would result in a much stronger flavor, maybe even overpowering.  2 + 1/2 hours seemed to be just right.  I will make this again.

This was FANTASTIC, will definitely make it again. I added some pressed garlic to the marinade, and before putting it in an onion-lined glass baking dish, I quickly pan-seared the roast on all sides at high heat. My oven tends to run a little low, so I upped the baking temp to 375, with the last 10 minutes or so going at 425 (but that was more for the benefit of the potatoes than the meat). Served it with roast potatoes, broccoli and carrots... my husband said I could make this ANY time. Sooo good, definitely recommended.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Most delicious pork I have EVER had.
I'm considering reposting the recipe because instead of putting it in the oven, I used my pressure cooker. It came out SO good. I used all the same ingredients, but I used 2.40 lbs of pork (what I had) and I added 1 cup of water and put it all right into the 6 qt. pressure cooker. NO MARINATING! Put in on the stove on high till it started rocking and knocked the heat down to medium to keep it moving gently. I let it rock for 40 minutes, then turned off the heat and let the pressure come down on it's own.
When I opened the cooker, the meat was falling apart and juicy and WONDERFUL. I will make this for everyone who will let me! I loved it.

Yum, yum, yum!  Even my 15 month old agrees.  This was sooo easy too.  I added garlic to the marinade but it probably didn't need it.  I also copied another reviewer and made a gravy with it.  It totally didn't need it, but I couldn't bear to just waste all that delicious marinade.  I separated out the oil first, then poured the marinade back in the pan, added some white wine, and thickened it up.  The gravy was outstanding although the pork itself was so good we barely touched it.  I think we'll appreciate the gravy when we heat up the leftovers though.  Or we might use it to liven up some turkey cutlets.  So many tasty options!

I marinated a 4 lb. pork loin for 4 DAYS in fridge a zip lock with aged Villa Manodori Balsamic Vinegar which is a sweet balsamic from Williams Sonoma and Montreal Steak Seasoning and some olive oil and this was perfect! Not vinegary at all as I think might be with a cheap brand. Cooked resting on top of sliced sweet potatoes and onion slices so as not to burn on the bottom. Served onto a big bed of white rice with a can of French Onion Soup and a splash of red wine added to make more gravy. So juicy and tender! My husband, college sons and friends ate it up! Thanks for making me the hero tonight!

country:
None
text:
Great starter recipe! Gave it a 4 because it needed longer to cook than suggested and it also needed a few tweaks or the vinegar taste (and yes we used high quality balsamic) would have been too strong. Modified as others suggested by adding minced garlic (lots), 2 tablespoons of honey, and an additional 1/2 cup of water near the end to make gravy. Marinated it for 24 hours. I watched it like a hawk so it wouldn't dry out while it was cooking. It took about 1 hour and 20 minutes until the pork was no longer pink for my 2 lb roast. I piled veggies (squash and red potatoes) around it and they had to be cooked longer to soften at a higher temp. Served this with gravy (just added cornstarch to the drippings) and homemade applesauce. Everyone raved about this recipe. It was by far the most tender pork I've ever eaten. This is a keeper!

text:
This was fast, easy & AWESOME!!!  I subbed Montreal chicken seasoning for the steak seasoning. Didn't have time to marinate or cook for one hour;therefore, I used a meat tenderizer to flatten the pork loin, then dunked loins into mix & placed on a baking sheet lined with release foil. Poured any remaining mix over the loins & cooked at 450 for 15 minutes...delicious, nutritious & QUICK....whole family loved it & there were no leftovers. We usually hate pork loin because it gets dry & tough so easily, but not this time!!!. Thanks Melissa for the spectacular recipe!!!  UPDATE: Tastes incredible with vegetables (marinate when making kabobs), chicken (tenderized & cooked in electric skillet) & tilapia (dipped fish in marinade, then breaded w/ Panko crumbs & baked for 15 minutes).  This is my go-to marinade recipe & I would give it 10 stars if I could..it is awesome with everything!!!

Used this recipe after hubby brought a pork tenderloin home unexpectedly.  I did use salt free steak seasoning(all I had), but did add my own salt. It turned out beautifully.  Very flavorful and moist.  Will most certainly use this recipe again.

text:
This is a easy & delicious way to prepare a pork loin roast.  I've made it several times and had rave reviews each time.  The roast is so flavorful and juicy!  I gave the recipe to both of my grown sons and they have prepared it for their friends and it was a hit every time!  One thing...do NOT marinate for longer than stated because it will make the roast taste too "vinegary".  If you stick to 2-3 hours maximum, you'll have success every time.  Note:  The gravy is delicious on mashed potatoes or rice!

text:
I love it when I can add another easy but fabulous tasting dish to my recipe collection.  Not only that, this is a two for one recipe.  I love Cipolline onions, those little flat onions that look and are the size of little door knobs, I usually braise them as a side dish but this time I just peeled them and added them to my roasting pan with the pork.  This is the only way I am going to fix them from now on.  I served this with a citrus salad  with baby greens and a loaf of French bread.  Dessert was simple too, one of my favorites from Italy; a scoop of vanilla ice cream, a few chopped walnuts and a tablespoon of chestnut honey.  This whole menu leaves plenty of time for visiting with guests.
The poor reviewer who threw out her roast, may have thought that "Balsamic" was a brand name?

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe for the first time a couple of days ago.  Like several other readers I guess I have cheap balsamic vinegar on hand because it turned out with a strong "wang" taste.  My 7yo son and I liked it but my wife did not.  So the next day I chopped 1/2 white onion and 1 green bell pepper that I sautéed in some leftover bacon grease from breakfast.  I then chopped up the rest of the pork loin and added a jar of BBQ sauce.  Mixed all of that together and let it simmer for 20min.  I plated the BBQ mixture on top of leftover mashed potatoes with green beans on the side.  The result was a very yummy tangy BBQ pork and best of all my wife liked it this time :).  And that's what matters.

text:
This was SO great! I read the reviews before starting and added carrots, onion and celery to the bottom of my glass dish set the pork on top of that and then put portabella mushrooms on top of that (they were on sale). I love vinegar so I had no issues with the smell. I brought it into work the rest of the week and every day I went to heat it up I was complimented on how wonderful it smelled. I bought a meat thermometer because some people were worried about the temp. This was my first experience using a meat thermometer so my readings came out all wacky. I stopped looking a it and just had the meat in there for 1 hour like it called for and it came out very nice. It had a light pink color in the middle. Not sure if this matters. I eat my steaks as rare as possible so pink and blood in any food never bothers me (iron stomach/immune system here). But I figured I would share my experience with you so you can make your own adjustments when making yours. I will definitely be coming back to this recipe again and again! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I cooked a large pork loin with this recipe.  I followed the directions to the letter and it turned out perfect.  The only thing I did change was prior to placing the meat in the oven I used my grill and seared the meat on very high heat to lock in the juices.  After the meat the seared I placed it in a cooking dish with the remainder of the marinade, which I used to baste the meat during the remainder of the cooking time.  Great recipe I would encourage anyone to use this.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I just finished this meal and was very happy that we both went for seconds.  I made a 3 lb. loin so I add a bit more of the steak rub seasoning and the balsamic.
As other reviewers recommended, I added vegetables (carrots and yellow onion) and minced garlic.  The flavor was very good but the steak marinade I used (Montreal Steak Seasoning) had quite a bite to it.
After, I took the pork and plated it to cool, and put the marinade in a small pot on low heat with Wondera and made a fantastic marinade...although when we cut the pork, it was so moist it didn't need it.
Great dinner, very happy with it and will definitely make it again, playing around with it...maybe adding honey as others suggested.
Thanks for this great recipe, I am not a "big" meat eater, but I will definitely make it again!

text:
This was really easy and delicious.  After marinating two hours, I cut slits in the top of the roast and inserted a mixture of minced garlic, dried rosemary and sage, plus a little Lawry's salt and pepper (which is how I would usually make it).  Spread the remaining paste across the top and sprinkled with Lawry's and pepper.  Then I added onion sliced to the bottom of the pan so they cooked in the balsamic/olive oil mixture.  All in all, really simple to make and a big hit at home!

text:
Loved the taste of this!!! I followed the directions for seasoning this, but it was so hot I didn't want to turn on the oven so I cut meat into 2 inch chunks after seasoning it, marinated for about 3 hours and then dumped meat & marinade into  a dutch over. Browned meat off on med-high& then lowered to med, covered it for about 20 minutes. YUM!!! Even my husband liked this & he's a very picky eater, Thanks for the great recipe. I'm thinking of doing this again & rolling in flour tortilla shells with sourcream & shredded cheese for a spicy pork sandwich.

Awesome flavor!  I did change a couple of things though.  I had taken out chicken for supper so I thought that I'd use this recipe but change it up abit.  I pounded the chicken flat and marinated them in the steak seasoning, oive oil, and vinegar mixture for 3 hours.  I then broiled them for 12 minutes.  They turned out awesome.  They were super moist and just delicious!  I plan on adding cajun seasoning next time I use it for chicken.  I'm planning on making a pork roast this week and I will be using this marinade...it has an awesome flavor!  Thanks so much Melissa for this one!

text:
Very good, but next time I will cut the olive oil in half. I see no reason for that much oil, it prevented the vinegar from reducing enough in the pan, and simply sat on top of the sauce. I ended up pouring it into a saucepan and cooking it down for a while, then spooned it out trying to leave most of the oil behind. It was very good then. My roast ended up a little dry, but ovens do vary and now I know to reduce the time a bit. Will make again.

this recipe is all you could want...absolutely simple to make...and marvelous to eat. The stuff about the vinegar smell while it cooked?? about 15 min in, there was an odor (not overpowering); it diminished as cooking continued. I cooked till temp was 140, took it out and tented it for 10 min-by then temp was right at 155, more than safe for todays pork. I have a moist, tasty roast. I even spritzed it with balsamic vinagrette dressing, I like the flavor so much!!! Will make this over and over!! I am looking forward to sandwiches with the leftovers.

Sooo good. I marinated a 3 1/2 lb. pork loin about 5 hours in a zip lock bag and made no substitutions. Baked it with an instant read thermometer to 145 degrees  (@ 350). I forgot to baste it until the last 10 min. but it turned out fabulous. It served 5 of us with leftovers for pork fried rice the next night.

text:
This is a go to recipe in our house. I use this steak seasoning from 17th St BBQ called Magic Dust. You can order it online and it is one of the best purchases I've ever made. We use it on everything!   I never marinate more than 2 hours because who really has time for that with jobs and kids.  I think the best tip I found in reviews is to add some honey.  It makes the recipe.   I just squirt some in the bag and I think it balances everything perfectly.  Honestly, this is our favorite thing to eat in this house!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I received flavored vinegars for a birthday gift, how delightful.  I used Fig Balsamic vinegar to make this dish and it was great (was torn between that and cherry balsamic), served with scalloped potatoes and fresh string beans and viola!! a great dinner had by all.  Thanks so much for this recipe.  I'm in unchartered waters when cooking with vinegar, but with balsamic, it just really kicks up the flavor of food.  I recently made chicken marsala and added a 1/4 cup of cherry balsamic vinegar to the wine, not knowing if I just blew this dish, and it was better than I ever made it.  Start using flavored vinegars gals, and your palette will love you for it.  BTW, when using vinegar in a baked dish, turn your head away from the oven door when you open it because that first waft of escaping hot air mixed with the vinegar smell will be stunning and almost overwhelming.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a PHENOMENAL tasting roast!!!  I had a pork loin, had the (quality) balsamic vinegar but didn't have steak rub in the house.  So I used Adobo.  I didn't dilute or dissolve the adobo, instead the loin had been frozen immediately at the time I purchased it and was put in a zip lock back to marinate in the balsamic.  Once it defrosted, I sprinkled the adobo all over and let it sit about 15 minutes to permeate the meat.  Then I baked at temp as directed but in a terracotta porcelain glazed baking dish.  AMAZING!!!  Seasoned mashed potatoes (home recipe) and Harvard beets, a dinner the whole family LOVED!  Just for the record, I repeated a similar process with a beef roast using zesty Italian dressing and adobo (also inserting several cloves of garlic into the roast) and it too was phenomenal!  That dinner got seasoned roasted red bliss potatoes and peas with pearl onions. DELISH!

Fabulous! Who knew a few simple ingredients could produce such amazing results! The only thing I changed was to add 2 cloves of minced garlic to the marinade. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/656325.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic!  Even my hubby, who hates any type of vinegar, said this was incredible!  Just before putting the tenderloin on the BBQ, I boiled the marinate, so I could brush it on the meat during cooking.  I also used it to dip french bread into during dinner.  I then seared the tenderloin on high (approx. 3 minutes per side), then turned the burner off, so the meat did not get direct heat.  Every 10 minutes or so, I would lift the lid and brush meat with marinate, turn it over, and brush it again.  after approximately 25 minutes, I inserted a meat thermometer into the side of the tenderloin so that the tip was in the center of the meat.  When it reached 145 degrees F, I removed the meat, covered it with foil, and let it rest.  I brushed the sliced french bread with olive oil and placed it onto the BBQ, while the pork was resting.  Once again, fabulous recipe.  Thanks Melissa S. for sharing!

city:

country:
None
text:
What I loved about this recipe was its simplicity, flavor, and I always have the available ingredients on hand.  What I didn't like was the salt, which is inherent in the steak seasoning.  For a two pound roast, I cut the ingredients in half and it was plenty of marinade.  Also, because of the salt, I recommend marinating for only 1-2 hours.  Definitely use a meat thermometer and take it out a bit early because it will continue to cook.  (Mine was a bit overdone.)  Next time I will cut the amount of steak seasoning and this should be perfect!  Thanks for sharing!

Delicious!  My son, who dislikes pork, told me he would eat pork as long as I prepared it in this way!  For those who thought the balsamic over-powered the meat must not be fans of balsamic vinegar. I took the advice of one reviewer and patted the roast with about 1/2 cup seasoned (onion & garlic power and dried rosemary & thyme) flour.  I also added 4 cloves minced garlic and 1/2 C white wine to marinade. Thanks for a terrific recipe, Melissa!

text:
I'm always a little worried that pork roasts will be too dry, but this was perfect! I used a garlic and herb steak rub with the balsamic vinegar, and the flavors blended very well. I will say that after an hour and reaching a temperature of 145 degrees, the center of my roast was still very undercooked. I put it back in the oven for about 15-20 minutes more until the temperature reached 160 degrees and it was amazing! Everyone in the family was asking for seconds and thirds!

userID:

Display Name:
KELLYANDMARK2
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!!  My "go to" pork roast recipe now.  My whole family (hubby and my dad especially) rave about this pork.  Definitely a dish to impress guests.   I take care of the roasting of the pork, then my husband makes a gravy with the drippings.  He pours the drippings into a gravy seperator, then pours everything but the fat into a saucepan.  He then adds a little white wine, sugar (to taste), and corn starch to thicken.  Just go light on the gravy when pouring over the pork until you figure out the right ratio of pork to gravy for your taste.  The gravy is strong, more of a "drizzling" sauce, than a gravy.

This was very good. It was a nice change from regular seared pork roast. I used a very expensive balsamic vinegar, and it did not taste like vinegar. This was a great recipe, We loved it the first time we had it.  The second time, I added some fresh garlic, a touch of honey, and a big dollop of dijon.  I took out the pan juices when the meat was at about 130 degrees and reduced them into a glaze that I used for basting in the final stages.  The result was a beautiful crust on the pork which itself was moist and flavorful.

I tried this recipe last night.  I had a 4.88 loin so I doubled the recipe.  I let it merinade for 6 hours.  I put it in the oven with a thermometer and 1 hour later I took it out.  The recipe said cook until temp reaches 145 degrees.  The meat was still bloody so I put it back in the oven until the temper reached 170 and yet it still had red areas.  Because it was so late I took some out and microwaves the meat so the kids could eat.  The flavor was good and the kids thought it was just OK.

text:
I really don't like pork loin or pork chops, but pork loin prepared this way is really good. Everyone else in the family will eat pork loin or pork chops any way you can make it, but I'm always on the lookout for ways to prepare pork that I am willing to eat.  Definitely marinate the loin overnight. It enhances the flavor so much. I put a few slits in the loin after marinating and before putting into the oven and basted it a few times during the cooking process. Really good. I will definitely be using this recipe any time my husband, who does the grocery shopping, brings home pork loin. Thanks for creating a pork recipe that I like!  Wonderful!

text:
This was excellent. The first time I made it, I used a balsamic that was aged 15 years in oak, so it was super mild and delicious. I loved the smell  of it cooking, and it wasn’t overly vinegary as a few have said. The second time, I made it for my son’s  family and they didn’t have the super aged balsamic, so I added quite a bit of honey to get it to the sweetness and consistency of my aged balsamic. Equally as good! This recipe is so easy and tastes so great, that I will be making this again and again! But the outcome will only be as good as the sweetness of balsamic you use.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We're vegan (oh, the irony), but I made this for my father-in-law--a man who is firmly entrenched in the 'meat and potatoes' camp.  While I think I may have slightly overcooked it, he raved about how the roast turned out and has claimed it as one of his favourite meals.  I used a good quality Balsamic vinegar and extra virgin olive oil for the marinade and made a steak rub from a recipe found on this site.  The house smelled amazing as the pork roasted (and for quite some time afterward), and the vinegar didn't seem to be at all overpowering.  I served it with sauteed spaetzle and Bavarian style sauerkraut with apples and caraway.  It looked gorgeous, and I have a feeling I will be making it as a 'gift meal' at least once per month!

text:
This recipe is fantastic and was a huge hit in my house tonight! I followed the recipe but did add some minced garlic to the marinade and put onions along the bottom of the dish before baking. I just happen to have a pretty good selection of balsamic, so I chose to use part raspberry blush and part aged Aceto Modena (10 yr). Now, I have no idea if using my choices or just good old Kroger brand really would have made a difference, as some other reviews have suggested, as this was my first time making this recipe. BUT it has now become a permanent addition to our home dinners and I’m very impressed. Easy recipe for anyone to follow and comes out beautiful, tender and flavorful. NOT Vinegar-y. I served mine over Parmesan Truffle couscous with a side of Italian broad (green) beans. Thank you for sharing your recipe with us!

text:
This is the best pork roast I've ever made!!  I've always tried to steer clear of the pork unless it was pulled pork or pork tenderloin because most pork is too dry for me.  I found a pork loin roast in the freezer (only God knows how long it was in there) and started looking for recipes.  This one had so many good reviews I just had to try it.  I didn't have quit enough Balsamic Vinegar so I did what someone else did and used part Red Wine Vinegar.  Can't wait to try full Balsamic, the glaze that comes from Balsamic can't be beat.  I marinated it over night and all day and threw it in the oven for exactly an hour at 350 and it was the bomb.  Hubby said to make sure I write this down in my recipe book so he can find it when he decides to cook.  Thank you for a great juicy and full of flavor pork roast.

country:
None
text:
I have made this 3 times now, and three different ways. The first was as the recipe was written with the only modification of adding minced garlic (WE LOVE GARLIC), and it was good. The second time was per recipe, but adding veggies and cooking in a slow cooker on low 8 hours. The meat was dry, and veggies needed either broth or extra marinade, not bad, just a little dry. This time I heeded another review and since I was cooking a 3# loin, I doubled the marinade, but did 1/2 cup balsamic vinegar, 1/2c white wine, 1c olive oil, 4T McCormick's Montreal Steak Seasoning, about 4T minced garlic, a generous squeeze of agave, didn't have honey for the marinade. Marinated overnight, then set roast down on a bed of sliced onions, poured marinade over and then surrounded roast with potatoes cut in 1/4's, carrots, celery and chopped onion. Because of the larger roast, cooked at 350 for 1hr 10mins under foil tent, removed foil and cooked another 20 mins. Removed roast and let set in foil while I turned veggies up to 450 and cooked another 20 mins. OMG delish and so moist! Great glaze on the veggies!!!! Thanks for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Made the recipe exactly as described and it turned out perfect both times! We used Trader Joe's balsamic vinegar (6% acidity, not sure if that's the main factor of sweetness) and it wasn't overwhelmingly tart.

I read about using metal bakeware versus glass bakeware and it's VERY important to use glass when making this dish: glass bakeware takes longer to heat up, but it maintains the heat over a long period of time. Metal bakeware heats up very quickly and is more suitable for when you want to brown things quickly (e.g: cookies). We also kept the marinade to use with the pork (we kept it in a tupperware in room temperature so the olive oil doesn't solidify).

100% would make again!

text:
This is another one where you CANNOT let the simplicity fool you!  My husband loved this so much, he can't stop talking about it.  I had a 4 lb. pork loin in the fridge, so I cut it in half and made one for us and one for my parents.  Holy moly, this is a good dish!  I took the advise of another reviewer and put thick slabs of red onion under the pork as it roasted and then served them over the meat.  OMG!  Also, I served with roasted potatoes and carrots. My husband devised the system of cutting each roasted potato into fourths, so there was more surface area for the balsamic sauce!  Do yourself a favor and try this one.  New favorite at our house, for sure.

text:
This was easy and great on the grill.  I used Costco balsamic vinegar and it tasted great and I'm not a balsamic vinegar lover.  I divided a 2 lb. loin into two parts  and marinated a few hours.  I cooked the loins for a total of ten minutes over high heat turning over once then cooked over low heat for twenty minutes basting a few times with the marinade.   I used my LP gas grill.  I mention this because if you use charcoal or a Natural Gas grill your times will vary.   My temp on the grill while at high heat was about 425 degrees and about 300 degrees with low heat.   
This is a keeper!

text:
The acid in the vinegar acts as a tenderizer, breaking down the fibrousness of the meat--you end up with really tender pork loin! I used a big tray of pork tenderloin medallions (just a pork loin cut up into individual servings) I purchased at Costco. I had planned to marinate it just 24 hours, but got busy, didn't cook dinner as planned, so the meat sat for a full 48 hours, which was a little worrisome. Nevertheless, the medallions were absolutely delicious. At 20 and 25 minutes the meat was still too rare. 35 minutes worked perfectly. Served this with hot buttered rice and roasted broccoli with Parmesan (also on allrecipes.com). My family loved this dish. For the steak rub seasoning I used Montreal Steak.

text:
Ding! Ding! Ding! -- Johnny, we have a winner!

Very simple recipe that turns out fantastic. This is in the "keeper" file for  sure. One family member isn't crazy about pork, but we converted her with this recipe. As others have suggested, don't skimp by using a cheap balsamic vinegar. I found a balsamic in the North End of Boston years ago (Rubio) which is a delicious, high quality balsamic. At $25-30 a bottle, I was a bit reluctant to use a half cup of it on a recipe I hadn't tried, so I mixed it about half and half with another decent balsamic that was about half the price. I may use all Rubio next time - I think it does make a big difference.

text:
This is wonderful. I followed the recipe as posted, marinading it overnight. The pork was moist and tender and very flavorful. I think the reviewer who suggested that the difference between loving it and thinking it was too vinegary was in the quality of the balsamic vinegar, and I whole-heartedly agree. I used a high-quality, (read: expensive) balsamic vinegar and there was really no vinegar smell at all in the marinade. Cheap balsamic vinegar can be quite harsh and I can imagine it would ruin this dish. This recipe is a keeper in my house.

text:
A hit at my house! I marinated as written but used a pork tenderloin. I’ve done this many times and we’ve always enjoyed it. I like to cook tenderloin to 145* , a little pink.(Salmonella is no longer a threat.) Tonight I took a suggestion from another reviewer and thick cut 2med onions, added some rough chopped garlic and some carrot slices, placed on baking sheet, poured marinade over veggies, laid tenderloin on top. Veggies were still crunchy after meat was done. Next time I’ll roast these veggies separately, or better, take out meat to rest and continue roasting those veggies. On a separate sheet, I made rosemary roasted red potatoes w/ the remaining carrot slices and those came out delicious! Thanks so much for this go-to marinade! I’ve used it on steak, too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe tonight and it was a HUGE hit, amazing and very easy recipe. I stuck pretty close to the recipe with a few small variations as previously recommended by other reviewers. I added 1/3 c. honey and 2 crushed cloves of garlic to the marinade. I let the pork marinade overnight. I also layered the pan with chopped onions when cooking. I cooked as directed at 350 x 55 minutes, uncovered. I cooked with diced gold potatoes, sweet potatoes and carrots. I removed the pork after 55 minutes and bumped up the oven temp to 375 , covered the pan with foil and cooked the veggies for 15 more minutes. This turned out AMAZING and my guests were raving about it. Fyi, I used Private Selection Balsamic Vin. and McCormick Montreal Steak Seasoning (for the steak rub). Must try!

text:
I can't remember ever being so conflicted about what rating I give a recipe.  First off, the flavor is fantastic! So I'll base my 5-star rating on that. I used Montreal Steak seasoning (McCormick) and the directed amount of vinegar and oil.  I marinated overnight and cooked to a temperature of 145 degrees using a meat thermometer.  My problem is this...I had very little liquid left after cooking, so I ended up mixing up an additional 1/2 batch to supplement what was there.  Maybe the baby carrots and 1/2 onion I added soaked up the liquid, but I sure didn't get the reduction that others described.  Bottom line is I'll definitely make it again, but will double the marinade.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is exactly what I look for on AR.com, quick, easy & versatile. This is a really good recipe as is, but there is So much space left on the canvas. Cooking is an art, use your imagination...you Love garlic...add garlic, add honey or whatever. I made this for the 2nd time & added a few extras. This is a Great marinade/sauce for many things. A warm potato salad, chicken, brushed on burgers, or anything on the grill...endless. Use Good balsamic & Good olive oil, it makes a huge difference. Also folks...learn the difference between a pork loin & a pork tenderloin. They are Not the same at all.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pork loin tastes absolutely amazing! I cooked this a couple of nights ago for my family and they couldn't stop eating it... Here's my 3 special ingredients: 1. I used a high quality balsamic (MiaBella Balsamic Vinegar, got it from Amazon). 2. I used McCormick's Grill Mates - Smokehouse Maple steak rub. 3. I added a teaspoon of minced garlic, then put it all together in a plastic bag in the fridge and let it sit for a full 24 hours. Took it out two hours before cooking to allow it to get to room temperature then cooked it at 375 degrees (not 350), and it was done to perfection in 50 minutes (must use a meat thermometer). Incredibly tender and full of flavor. You will love it!

Simple and delicious recipe! This would be excellent as-is, but I added some chopped onion and minced garlic to the marinade because we are onion and garlic freaks.  Also I added some quartered fingerling potatoes and baby Portobello mushrooms to the baking dish as a side dish.  I used a half-way decent balsamic vinegar ($10ish for a bottle) and it was not overpowering at all. Everyone in my family loves this recipe!

text:
Loved this recipe.  Made it about 5 days ago with a pork loin. Marinated it over night/actually for 24 hrs, and it was just so flavorful and awesome.   Yesterday I used the same basic balsamic recipe with little different mix of spices and marinated boneless chicken breast for 24 hrs and used it cut up for shish kebobs on the grill. YUM! Also cooked up two extra breasts and cut up into strips and froze in separate ziplocks and will take out to use on fresh green salads. No buying the pre-packaged cooked meats with extra junk in them.  .. This basic recipe can be switched up a bit with different spices and used in all kinds of meats!

None
text:
The price of the balsamic vinegar has a lot to do with how strong it is. However, you can use inexpensive balsamic vinegar by heating it to evaporate the acetic acid. You'll smell it if you're sensitive, so use your exhaust fan. I use "the cheap stuff" which I reduce by 1/3 then add back either water or rice wine vinegar for a milder flavor.

None
text:
This is an incredibly good and simple recipe.  Key to this recipe is to use a good aged balsamic vinegar…one that has some body to it. My tenderloin was a little under 2lbs so was done in 45 mins and still a hint of pink in the middle. To the reviewer that cooked theirs for an hour and it was still "hard" I suspect you might have used a pork loin and not a tenderloin. To the reviewer that says you should never eat pork that is still pink…in this day an age pink (not rare) pork is perfectly safe and is much preferred  by many folks including me.

None
text:
So simple but sooo good!  I used a very nice, satuma mandarin balsamic, made my own simple steak rub (1 part pepper, 1 part garlic powder, 4 parts kosher salt), and EVOO on a roast from a home raised hog.  The kids wanted another dish the day I planned this and, since they volunteered to cook, I let the roast marinate until the next day.  Cooked it in a glass pan at 350 degrees until the meat thermometer read 145 degrees.  Took it out, let it rest, and cut it - like butter.  I thought it might taste fairly tangy but no.  It was moist,  not too sweet, not too tangy.  It was deliciously flavorful but did not overwhelm the pork itself.  Perfecto!  The whole family loved it.  I will make this again and will try adding sliced onion, as others suggested, just for fun.

text:
I like pork loin, I like balsamic vinegar, so I thought I'd love this recipe. I read the reviewers' comments, and made sure that I used a high quality aged balsamic vinegar and didn't over marinate.  When it was baking, the smell was sharp/pungent and overwhelming, and I wished I was not in the house. The first time I opened the oven to ladle sauce over the loin, my eyes and nose burned. When my husband came home, he said, "What is that smell..I thought you were roasting pork loin?"

Fast forward to when it was served....it was tender, juicy and flavorful. Hated the smell, though..which is still pervasive throughout the house. Definitely not a dish I would make for company.

Gave it 5 stars due to it's simplicity and great taste. Did add 2 large crushed garlic cloves to marinade and added 2 sliced med onions to bottom of the pan before adding roast on top . The addition of the onions gives it added moisture and taste. If you use a decent quality balsamic vinegar, you shouldn't need to add any honey as some others have, otherwise I feel this would be too sweet. It's great as is!

text:
I've made this recipe over a dozen times over the past couple of years. I always add 3 tablespoons of minced garlic and use Old Bay, rather than steak seasoning. It's always a big hit and a very easy meal to prepare, especially if you're hosting a dinner party and need to focus on other items, such as appetizers, side dishes, and deserts.  
I've found that cooking it in my convection microwave oven on "combo" cuts the cooking time to half and creates a beautiful brown color, while locking in the juices.  This also frees up the oven for other items that require different temperatures.

text:
This is the perfect recipe to use with a Trader Joe's pork roast. The average TJs pork roast will feed 3 or 4 adults for one night, or a couple adults for a good 2 nights. This marinade is so quick and delicious. I like to mix it in a measuring cup and just pour it into a large Ziploc with the roast in the morning, then it's ready to go into the oven as soon as I get home from work. Comes out nice and juicy, perfectly done. If I'm out of steak seasoning I just get creative with ground peppers and spices! It's always good!

text:
This was wonderful! I am in the process of making it a second time.  The only change that I made was to cut the marinade recipe in half.  It definitely does not need a whole cup of marinade for a roast this size.  Our 2 pound roast fit perfectly in a 1 quart Ziplock bag.  I put the roast in, then poured in the marinade (which was 1/4 cup of EVOO & 1/4 cup balsamic marinade plus 1 T steak seasoning) squeezed out the air and zipped it up.  I used Costco steak seasoning which was too salty for us when used alone on a steak but when mixed with the balsamic vinegar and oil it was perfect! I am also delighted to find a way to use it up too.

text:
The marinade was very good on the meat.  My suggestion to those who might use the marinade to roast accompanying vegetables is to use a fairly mild steak spice.  Otherwise, the marinade can overpower the great natural flavours of roasted vegetables.  I roasted potatoes, carrots, parsnips, beets, brussel sprouts and onions with the meat and it was a great meal and only the roasting pan to clean up!

Great recipe but waste of time marinating it or marinating anything since whatever you're marinating does not absorb the marinade.  Best to just cook it and either baste it while cooking or pour the marinade over the meat after it's cooked.  Read more about marinating to be better informed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish absolutely lives up to its billing.  It is wonderfully moist and flavorful, not to mention easy to prepare.  With a high quality balsamic it neither smells like vinegar nor tastes like vinegar.  After reading a number of the reviews I chose a black cherry balsamic to enhance the flavor of the pork and used Rub with Love steak rub.  Also from reading the reviews I decided to try making a sauce with the drippings.  I made something up using the go-to sauce base my grandmother used:  1/3 cup brown sugar and 2 tsp. corn starch.  To prepare the sauce I skimmed off some of the fat from the drippings, added the remaining drippings to a sauce pan and brought them to a boil.  In a separate dish I combined the brown sugar and corn starch until well mixed.  Once the drippings were boiling, remove from the heat and slowly stir in the brown sugar and corn starch mixture until thickened.  The sauce with the black cherry flavor was delicious and wonderful for each guest to add to their taste at the table.  Next time, I might add a few fresh black cherries...but then again maybe not.  This dish was simply amazing and enjoyed by all!

text:
I made this last night using a very aged balsamic I save for special dishes.  It made it a little too sweet for me so next time I will use my regular balsamic.  I don't use steak seasoning so I added my own spices.  I had to add additional liquid to the pan so used white wine and then made gravy while the roast rested.  I also added a large onion cut in wedges to the marinade and roasted them with the roast.  Everything was delicious and my husband loved it.  Served with fresh mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli.
Always use a good aged balsamic, the cheap stuff isn't worth it.  However the more aged it is the sweeter it gets!

userID:
4886888
Display Name:
Doctor Greg
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/416445.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is so important to chose the right balsamic vinegar....If you use a well-seasoned (costs more and is more sugary/less acidulous) the result is excellent.  My variant doesn't change the flavor that much but seals in the juices before roasting and gives a much more attractive presentation.  Same ol' prep with the resealable bag, and one SMALL crushed garlic clove (don't overdo it, folks), and a half tsp of erbes de Provence (the thyme and rosemary enhance and give structure to the balsamic vinegar) without overpowering the delicacy of the roast.  Hey, if you can't get that SUPER aceto balsamico from Modena (it's 20 minutes from Bologna where I live) add a tbsp of brown sugar or honey to the marinade.... that works, too.  THEN!!!!  Before you put it in the roasting pan and in the oven, brown that dude on all sides in some hot olive oil and one tbsp butter (don't let it smoke!!!)  to seal in the goodies.  Try it, you'll like it...  It becomes a 5 star PLUS if you poke a dozen or so whole cloves in the upper surface.  While it's cooking, I can assure you that you won't be tempted to throw it out for the smell of vinegar!!  If the doorbell rings it's one of the neighbors who wants to know what you're cooking. :-)

This was very tasty! Nice strong flavors from the steak seasoning with a slight tang from the balsamic vinegar. I used 1 packet of 'McCormick Grill Mates Montreal Steak seasoning' and marinated for 12 hours. And I used boneless pork chops instead of a whole pork loin. I thickened the sauce by making a slurry using 2 Tbls. dry red wine with 2 Tbls. cornstarch. It worked perfectly and I think it needed it. The red wine complemented the sauce perfectly. I think I'll try this recipe with chicken cutlets next time! A great easy recipe!

text:
This was a good recipe, although I deviated from the original a bit. I want to preface by saying remember pork can be a little pink inside. I chopped some celery to use as a "heat buffer" in the bottom of my roaster pan (instead of glass dish). Carrots, celery, and apples make great buffers. I also put a cup of stock in the bottom of the pan and tented the roast for the first 35 minutes of cooking. It was uncovered for the next 35, totaling 1hr 10 minutes. Tender, flavorful, will do this again.

Display Name:
Linda Andersen Mangold

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this last night with some of the changes reviewers suggested.  Here's what I did:  Marinated for four hours,followed marinade recipe but added a tablespoon or so of honey, added potatoes and carrots.  What I would do different:  We like balsamic vinegar so I would leave out the honey as it took away alot of the tang.  If I added anything I would add molasses instead (trust me - really great flavor), waaaaay to much oil and I cut it to 1/3 C; otherwise it smothers the balsamic flavor.  I don't think it needs more than 1/4C at most.  Forgot to add the sliced onions (duh) and they are a must (delicious in balsamic)so won't forget next time, would marinate overnight for more flavor, make potatoes very small and carrots sliced (not chunked)as they don't cook in an open pan in one hour. Lastly, I didn't have time to make a gravy with the juices and there was alot of juice.  That would have added flavor to the meat and veggies.  This is a great starter recipe and I think you just have to fiddle with the marinade depending on how much you like balsamic vinegar and definitely use good stuff.  The cheap stuff or old vinegar can get too vinegar-y and balsmic should be sweet enough to eat from a spoon.

text:
This was all right.  I marinated it about 6 hours.  I think it would be better if it was marinated longer.  It has a great flavor and seasoning on the outside of the roast.  I'm not sure the cooking instructions are the best.  I cooked it exactly as written.  I took it out after one hour and it was 145 degrees.  It rose to about 160 upon sitting.  When I cut it, the middle was a bit rare and the ends were dry.  Not a terrific result, but the family ate it with very few leftovers, and it was very easy. (I think pork loin is too lean to be reliably moist every time so I wouldn't blame the recipe for this.)

text:
RIDICULOUSLY DELICIOUS! I read many, but not all reviews. I too follow recipes to the letter the first time. And if you don't, you should submit your own recipe because you're not rating the true recipe. I make it as written first, then if I make chages, I note accordingly, but only and always after I've tried it as written first. That said, I've made this twice now. The first time, exactly as written. Beautifully delicious and because of income constraints, used store brand balsamic. When I opened the oven door to check temp, I was overwhelmed a bit with the vinegar vapors, as was the downstairs. DO NOT let this stop you or even more stupidly, throw out a perfectly good roast. It does NOT taste like a vinegar concoction. It reduces to a seductively delicious roast. The second time I did add two finely chopped minced garlic cloves to the marinade. I was out of olive oil, so used Wesson. Out of steak seasoning so used Cavander's Greek. And I rough chopped an onion to create a bed upon which to place the roast. STILL amazing! Biggest key: We like a pink center so I don't cook it beyond 145 degrees. Forget time and use an instant read thermometer. This recipe will impress! Thank you, Melissa!

This was just okay. I also didn't enjoy the vinegar aspect, although upon reading other reviews it may be because my bottle had been open and in the fridge for a while. text:
I rarely give anything a 5* rating, but this one is super. I used a single packet of McCormick Grill Mates Garlic-Herb-Wine marinade and added 1.5 Tbsp granulated garlic [hate vampires! ;-)]. I scored the loin *very* deeply in an 1" (approx) crosshatch pattern square to the long access of the loin, leaving only the bottom 1 to 1.5" uncut. I filled the cuts with marinade and put directly into the oven. I'm certain allowing the marinade to seep into the meat would make this about a 5.5 recipe. This is *THE BEST* pork roast I've ever had, in fact the first one I've ever truly enjoyed. This has elevated pork roast from an occasional, obligatory, barely tolerable, alternative protein dish to a frequent, First Class, flier.
Review:
Rating:
5

This was wonderful! Hubby hates vinegar. He never knew it was there. I scraped the bottom of the pan, added a little more olive oil and white wine in a pan. text:
I was willing to try this after reading the reviews, although my daughter doesn't like most pork roasts or pork chops.  I will mention that when it says a glass baking dish, it must mean a smaller one!  I marinated mine beginning in the morning, using steak seasoning I bought at Aldi's.  It WAS great!  Even the non-pork roast eating daughter liked it, her boyfriend loved it!  I thought it was tasty myself.  After feeding 3 adults and a toddler, there was just enough left to pack my daughter's boyfriend lunch!  I served it with the Butter Pecan Sweet Potato recipe I got from Pinterest, which was also a hit, stewed cabbage, and crispy cornbread cakes.  Yummy!

I'm adding this 18 months or so after trying it the first time.  My family still loves it and looks forward to eating it.  I'm not sure how it turned out dry for anyone, but keep in mind that the author shows it in a small glass dish for roasting, looks like an 8 x 8 or 9 x 9, I think that affects how much marinade you have at the end.  We're eating it tonight with some roasted sweet potatoes and creamed spinach!  FYI, I usually forget to baste it and it's still juicy!

None
text:
AMAZING!!!! I have never left a review for a recipe on here before but I felt I had to in this case. Everyone loved this roast at my house today! I had a larger roast not a loin, I made a rub using a mixture of season salt and brown sugar and rubbed it liberally all over the roast and then seared it on all sides. I then placed it in a glass dish and dumped the balsamic/olive oil and vinegar mixture on top and roasted it at 350 covered with foil for two hours. After about two hours I dumped in some baby carrots and added a little brown sugar on top and let it cook for about 30 more minutes. Let it rest for a few and then slice, best roast Ive ever made!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't have steak seasoning so I subbed with Mc Cormick's Grill Mates Montreal Chicken Seasoning and rubbed it on the meat and then added the marinade and let it marry overnight till dinnertime.  Tried it with pork tenderloin 2lbs. My 1st time making this. Results, amazing!

2nd time I used boneless skinless chicken thighs and grilled it. Great too!  I did splash some more balsamic vinaigrette (Newman's Own Lite) near the end of grilling.  I prefer the oven because it's more flavorful with pan juices for basting.   3rd time I used 4 1/2 lbs pork loin and used original marinade and let it marry for 48 hours.  Oven roasted the pork loin with marinade and made a gravy with the juices.  Got rave reviews on the gravy especially (from the marinade and not discarding it but cooking it with the pork) also the pork was so tender. Fussy eater said he wants the marinade recipe and my gravy that was from the marinade.  Just added cornstarch, water and salt as needed for the gravy using the juices & whisk in till desired gravy consistency.  Eyeball it.  Highest compliments ever!  Thank you.

The whole thing was cooked to perfection.

country:

text:
Great reciepe,i changed it up a bit. Used 1/3 cup balsamic vinger, 1/3 cup of white wine, 1tbsp of honey,1/2 cup of olive oil, my own chicken seasoning with paprika, two sprigs of rosemary, and 1/4 cup of brown sugar marinaded it over night.  Preheated the oven to 350, cut of potatoes,carrots and sweet potatoes and two big onions. Placed the onions on the bottom as suggested in several reviews, placed the roast ovet the onions and the potatoes around the outside of the roast and the carrots on top. Cooked it for one hour then tuned down to 325 for another hour. Removed the meat and the vegs and made gravy with the drippingfrom the roadt. Thanks foreveryones help, it came out great!

text:
We really, really loved this with roasted potatoes and roasted asparagus. We poured the balsamic reduction right over all three. My only issue is that there's so much leftover olive oil I wound up using the ziploc bag trick to strain it out so we didn't wind up eating it - yick. I feel that you could get away with manually rubbing the roast down with oil and then just using 2 TB in the marinade. Granted I haven't tried it that way, so perhaps that's a terrible idea, but it's what I'm going to try next time. Thanks for the recipe, we absolutely licked our plates, the sauce was so good! P.S. I used Penzey's "Chicago Steak Seasoning" mix for the steak rub.

userID:
5826853
Display Name:
Lisaz8605
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a great technique! What an easy way to prepare a lovely meal!! I didn't have steak seasoning on hand, so I just threw the vinegar, oil, roast and some other seasonings in a bag...plus minced garlic...and threw the whole thing in the fridge. As a busy mom and caregiver to my mother, I simply don't have time to make complicated meals but I want to feed my family good food at a good price. This fit the bill. I loved taking the entire contents out of the bag and throwing it in a glass dish in the oven. Great tip on basting too. When I baked it, I added thyme and rosemary, which I think pair well with pork.

My one suggestion would be to find a way to balance the tang of the vinegar, so as one reviewer mentioned, I might try a little honey next time. I could see adding a little honey and mustard glaze before baking as well. I do think marinating with the vinegar worked like a charm. This was the most tender pork roast I've made in ages. Next time I might also stop roasting a little earlier and do a final broil to create a crust. But the taste and tenderness made up for the crust I usually like.

As far as application, not only is this a lovely roast (which I served with couscous and broccoli) but it also makes for a phenomenal sandwich! Hubby came home late and enjoyed it on a kaiser roll. I look forward to using it in a sandwich I adore with basil mayo and havarti. Yum.

I made a large, 5 lb pork loin roast so had to cook longer...about 1 1/2 hours.  After about 45 min., I sliced a Vidalia onion and roasted w/ it and added some ginger jam to the sauce.  I steamed some carrots and sugar snap peas and then mixed in w/ the sauce after it was done.  I think it is ready when temp. reads 140 b/c 145 overcooked it a little.  It was delicious and will make it again.

This was pretty good, but although I cooked it until the internal temp was 158, it was still a little pink in the middle after marinating for 2 days. It was a little disturbing. I shredded it and slow-cooked it in broth for 4 hours and used it for French dip sandwiches, which we all enjoyed. I prefer another recipe, but I was glad to try this. Thanks for posting!

text:
Thank you for a good, simple, flexible recipe!  I didn't have enough balsamic vinegar so I used balsamic vinegar and sherry vinegar.  I also used some garlic flavored olive oil.  My pork loin was much smaller so it didn't require a very long cooking time.  Make sure you consider this when planning...you don't want to overcook this yummy pork loin!  I served it with roasted butternut squash.

region:

country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe as it is written. I only marinated for 2 hours because that is all the time I had. The flavor was strong, but I still might try marinating it longer next time to see how the flavor changes. It took just under an hour to cook. The meat was moist and tender. The flavor was pretty good, but I think next time I will try 1/3 cup of vinegar and oil.  It seemed a little heavy for my tastes. The quality of the flavor relies a lot on what kind of steak seasoning you use. If you don't quite dig it the first time, try using a different kind of seasoning. I definitely enjoyed this dish. I will most likely make it again.

text:
I was really worried about it because I didn't read the review about cheap vinegar until it was too late and all I had was the great value brand.  I used Grill Creations steak dust instead of rub and I added a tsp of garlic powder.  I put it on the grill instead of the oven as to not take the chance of making my house smell like vinegar.  Also in the last 5-10 min I put about a 1/4 cup of brown sugar and 1/4 cup of hot water together and basted the roast with it.  It was EXCELLENT, my whole family loved it and I didn't even get the smallest taste of vinegar, just a real good flavor throughout and really juicy, the wife says this definitely goes in the reciepe box.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been looking for a recipe like this to make Balsamic Chicken. This was very good. But I did take it one step further. I put the juices from the roast, actually the store didn't have a roast so I used thin loin chops, and 4 pork chops instead. I marinated in a freezer bag and then stacked them in the baking dish. When they were done baking, I then poured the juices into a frying pan, and added sliced portobello mushrooms. That simmered and reduced until much of the juices had caramelized on the bottom of the pan. I added flour, a tablespoon or so, and some water, continuing to simmer until I had a light gravy. The gravy was excellent over mashed potatoes, but could also have it over garlic mashed potatoes.

text:
This was SOOOO yummy!  I made it exactly to the recipe directions and it was really easy!  I used Grill Creations Kansas City Style steak seasoning, marinated about 3 hours and cooked at 350 for a little over an hour because my roast was about 2 and 1/2 pounds.  It was not only yummy but the marinade poured over the top before cooking gave it a beautiful textured appearance when I took it out of the oven.  It was little too salty for our taste so I'll probably cut back on the steak seasoning next time.

Display Name:
D'nini

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AWESOME.  Great marinade.  For the steak seasoning, I used Trader Joe's 'Spices of the World' 21 SEASONING SALUTE. It is salt free and all natural.  As the label suggests, it contains 21 different spices & is far better than Emerils (spicy) or Montreals (too salty) and less expensive.  I reduced the balamic vinegar to a little less than 1/2 cup.  That is the only change I made. Turned out fantastic  I do have a suggestion.  It would be helpful if the recipe named the type of pork loin roast tp use.   Pork loin comes in various 'cuts' & some can be very 'dry'.  There is boneless center cuts (too dry), outside & inside loin cuts,  pork loin 'sirloin', and tenderloin.  The butcher suggested the boneless 'inside' pork loin roast.  Very tender and flavorful.  With the exception of 'tenderloin', this is the best pork loin roast we have enjoyed.  Will definitely make this again.

Anyways, it didn't have any great flavor, the middle part which was still tender was good but the outsides were overcooked. I won't make this again.

text:
I could hardly wait to finish eating to write this review! This was delicious! I had to do things a little differently though. I thought I had balsamic vinegar, turns out it was red wine vinegar. I thought well...I'll try it anyway. I also used extra virgin olive oil and Montreal steak seasoning. I put the pork loin in a gallon size Foodsaver bag (it was almost 3 lbs.) along with the mixed ingredients. Then I vacuum sealed it and put it in the frig. around noon today. I started cooking about 5 tonight and thought I had made a huge mistake! The entire house smelled like red wine vinegar. (VERY STRONG) I thought well we'll see what happens. It turned out absolutely perfect! I cooked it for 1 hr. checked the temp and it was at 150. I removed and let sit for 10 minutes while I made mashed potatoes and heated green beans. It was so juicy and flavorful, but not overpowering at all. I can't wait for leftovers tomorrow night!

text:
This was a super simple recipe.  I didn't have enough balsamic vinegar, so i used a 1/4 cup of honey.  I also didn't have enough steak rub, so I used some salt free grilled chicken seasoning.  I grilled the pork loin over medium heat for 55 minutes, turning it after the first 10 minutes to sear the juices in.  This turned out so juicy and tasty, I will definitely be making this again.

text:
Pressed for time, I chose this recipe because it was fast, easy, and called for few ingredients.  I was nervous because my husband is usually very picky when it comes to marinades - he hated the last few.  But he LOVED this marinade and couldn't believe how simple it was.  It's been several days since we ate the pork, but he's still talking about it!  The only variance from the recipe was that I cooked my pork in a rotisserie for about 30 minutes.

Sensational. I marinated my pork loin overnight.  I sliced a large red onion and marinated it in balsamic vinegar and salt and pepper overnight as well.  I grilled the red onions on my George Foreman grill while the pork loin was in the oven.  Absolutely delicious.  I served this with the Roasted Potatoes and Green recipe from this site and it was one of the best meals ever.  Very elegant and somewhat gourmet ! Thanks !

text:
I saw a lot of reviews commenting that the pork was too vinegary.  I think success with this recipe mostly depends on the quality of the balsamic vinegar.  For about $20 you can buy a pretty good bottle and it will last quite sometime.  If your vinegar is cheap, it may as well be white vinegar.

text:
I scaled this recipe to serve four because I had one lb. of pork tenderloin. I didn't change anything else and used Montreal steak seasoning for the rub. It made a very moist tenderloin and did take the full hour to cook completely. I think next time I will add minced garlic to the marinade and make sure to only leave it in for two hours as three and a half hours made it a little too vinegary and salty for our taste. A very easy and quick recipe that I will definitely make again, Thank you.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/332607.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night for my family.  I only had 1/4 cup of olive oil so I halved the marinade recipe and used a 3 lb boneless pork loin roast.  The marinade actually seemed quite sufficient. I chopped a whole white onion and put it on the bottom of my crock-pot, followed by about 5 quartered red potatoes and then the roast w/ marinade.  I cooked it on high for 2 hours, then put to low for 4 more (until internal temp was 170.) With about 2 hours remaining, I added a few handfuls of baby carrots.  Roast and veggies had good flavor but roast was a little on the dry side... could be from halved marinade?  I strained the juices in the pot and made a gravy but will just use a jar of pork gravy next time as what I made was too tangy for our tastes due to the balsamic vinegar.

text:
Great recipe!  The perfect thing when you need something fantastic and you don't have 10,000 ingredients.  

I used a pork shoulder and also seasoned with McCormick spicy Montreal steak seasoning.  Once the roast was done, I added about 1/3 cup of brown sugar to the pan drippings and let it cook down to thin ketchup consistency (it will thicken with cooling).  WOW.  It became THE most sweet/savory/spicy, homemade version of Pickapeppa/A1 sauce ever.  My family loved the roast, but I think we loved that leftover sauce even more!  I made simple sandwiches using leftovers on hoagie rolls with mayo and the "magic sauce" that were to die for...

Really enjoyed this easy recipe!  I used approx 3-4 pounds pork loin fillets and marinated 18 hours.

text:
Excellent for New Years day dinner! I used Musini White Truffle Balsamic Glaze which is very concentrated, so I used 1/4 C and 1/3 C olive oil. I marinated it overnight and turned it several times while marinating. 
The pork loin was flavorful, juicy and made a great presentation for a holiday meal. The clean up was a messy issue because of the sugars in the balsamic vinegar. I saved some of the juice/marinate with the leftovers, but the remaining burned juice in the pan needed to be soaked overnight to clean. I am so glad I made it, because this will be made many more times in the future.

userID:
4420869
Display Name:
SoCalAngel
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
475
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/341357.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is delicious exactly as written, but after reading the reviews, I decided to make some additions. I used a 3.5 lb center cut, boneless pork roast. I used 1/3 c of Kirkland brand olive oil & 1/3 c of Kirkland balsamic vinegar. I added 3 large cloves pressed fresh garlic & 1/3 c honey to the marinade, mixed well and put it all in a large ziplock bag. I marinated for just over 24 hrs. That did the trick! Cooked @ 350 degrees & it took a little over 2 hrs to reach 160  degrees, using an instant read thermometer inserted into the center. The honey gave it a nice caramelized glaze & the sweetness balanced well with the balsamic vinegar. The garlic gave it extra savory flavor. Don’t leave out the garlic! I sliced a large onion into thick slices and put them in the bottom of the pan, so the roast wouldn’t stick. I used a disposable aluminum baking pan, the size of a rectangle cake pan, for easy clean up. I wouldn’t use a very deep sided pan for this. Low & slow is the way to cook this because it came out so tender, it was heavenly. This is easy to make & you can serve this to company. Serve with roasted cut up sweet potatoes or baby potatoes. I used some of the pan juices over the meat. This is going into my repertoire for pork dishes! Loved it!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-11-11T15:15:57.227

text:
I made this on the...green ceramic grill/smoker.  I soaked hickory wood chips and added a handful on every ~15 minutes.  I grilled until the pork loin read 145 degrees in the center, then took it off the fire and let it rest under loose aluminum foil for 15 minutes.   We served it with sweet corn risotto and spinach salad.  And a glass of wine.  Good stuff!

Very good. Just a few changes to suit our flavor profiles.
Added minced garlic and rosemary (both fresh)to the marinade omitted the maple syrup since we prefer savory to sweet. 
I did marinate overnight, reserving some of the marinade. We BBQ’d the lion roast basting with half of the reserved marinade... 
Served with rosemary garlic roasted red potatoes and asparagus also roasted during last 15 minutes of cooking the potatoes. Drizzled the remaining marinade on the asparagus just before serving.  Delish!

country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe, so simple and easy to throw together. I used Montreal steak spice and a new but inexpensive bottle of balsamic vinegar and didn't have any issues with the flavour. Marinated for several hours, then after I removed the pork from the marinade I tossed a bag of cut veggies (broccoli, cauliflower, and baby cut carrots) plus some red onion in the left over marinade, then cooked in the same dish with the pork (poured the remaining marinade over everything) Turned out great! Will be making this one again for sure.

I'm on the fence about this one. I like that it's really easy and has only a few ingredients. What I didn't like was the sharp taste the balsamic vinegar imparted on the overall taste. I used very good quality vinegar but I still felt it was the wrong mix of flavors. I'm sure a lot of my friends would like this but I'm a bit warm on it. I may try it again using half as much of the vinegar. If so, I'll report back.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night and it was delicious. I took some of other reviewers suggestions like adding chopped scallions and parsley in the marinade. I also cooked it on a bed of sliced onions. After cooking, I put the remaining marinade and onions into a saucepan, added beef broth, a little wine and some bottled balsamic glaze and dissolved some cornstarch in a bit of broth and added that in to slightly thicken it. Poured it over the sliced meat before serving. I cook boneless pork tenderloin in a way I learned on this website. Heat oven to 500 degrees. Put room temperature pork loin into the oven and put timer on for 7-8 minutes per pound. Then TURN OFF OVEN without opening the door and put the timer back on for 50-60 minutes. I like 50 minutes as when removed from oven it continues to cook when put on cutting board and tented with foil for at least 10 minutes. Perfect every time.

city:
