country:
None
text:
Wow What a surprise. I had a little bit of a different situation where I had an 8 pound loin because there was a really good sale at the supermarket. It ended up getting cut in half but I cooked both at the same time. I tripled the marinade recipe. I read alot of the reviews and yes - it will make your house smell very vinegary but the end flavor is so much better than expected. Even my son commented that he expected it to taste more like vinegar. I added some garlic and a touch of honey as suggested by another poster. I let  them marinade for about 24 hours flipping after 12. I may have cooked them a touch too long but they were delicious. I cooked them on a rack since I didn't trim the fat before marinating and I didn't want them swimming in fat drippings. I think next time I might try pounding them (or it if they're not on sale :) ) before I marinade . Will definitely make again!

text:
I added Brussels Sprouts (halved) and cut up pieces of bacon that I had rendered in a fry pan for a bit (to remove a bit of the fat) to the roasting pan.  The bacon and sprouts were tender and yummy.  The Roast was just a bit dryer than I like it, and my husband commented on the dryness, too.  I cooked it for one hour at 350 and used a probe thermometer  as well.  The timer for the oven and the temperature alarm went off at exactly the same time.  
  I will make this again, but I will probably cook it to 137 and let it coasts to 145.

text:
Delicious!
I marinated the roast over night with the ingredients the recipe call for. I did bake the roast for 45 mins at 350' and then turned the oven up to 450' and baked the roast for another 10mns just as another reviewer did. Make sure to cover the roast with foil and let it rest a good ten minutes when it come out of the oven. I also added potato quarters. I did bake those an additional 15 mins. The roast was so tender and juicy. My family loved it, dog included. This will be my go to recipe for pork ribeye roast.

country:
None
text:
I hardly ever review anything but the boyfriend says this is in the top favorite things I’ve made for him so credit is due! I’ve made this recipe 3 times now and yes, I’ve made some modifications according to our taste but the original recipe was delicious as well! I placed sliced onions on the bottom of the pan and set the loin on top before baking. I also added some honey and lots of garlic to the marinade. When a recipe is so simplistic, make sure to use quality ingredients, especially the balsamic vinegar!

country:
None
text:
Mixed the marinade as directed and marinated Pork loins for approximately 6 hours.  I smoked the meat at 325 degrees with Cherry wood using my Traegger grill.  Meat was turned every fifteen minutes and marinated during turn cycle until meat reached internal temperature of 155 degree which was roughly 45 minutes.  Meat was both moist and very flavorful.  I am really looking forward to eating left over pork loin tomorrow night.

text:
So tender! I marinated the meat with some typical spices, and 1/2 cup of the balsamic, white cooking wine and 1/4 cup garlic/lemon EVOO. Added some garlic to the mix and it was awesome. Put in plastic bag in fridge for about two hours. Took about 1.5 hours in oven on 350. Had a side of cauliflower mashed potatoes and used the left over marinade from the oven. This is a keep recipe for my family!

It was very good. We grilled it though because we prefer the flavor. 5 stars for the actual flavor of the recipe. 1 star for the internal meat cooking temperature suggested. I took it to a potluck where of course there was too much food and plenty of leftovers - except for this roast. Every bite of it was gone. People obviously went back for seconds. I'm going to try this method on a rump roast I am thawing. Hoping it is just as good.

This is *very* good - we only had two double-thick cuts of pork loin, not a whole pork loin roast, so I just halved the recipe.  I'd gotten a lovely balsamic vinegar at a Christmas craft fair last year, and used the last of that on this dish. Definitely a keeper.

userID:
1709101
Display Name:
Marcia
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/940208.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nice flavor, and very tender and juicy. I didn’t plan ahead so only had 1 hour to marinate. I pre-sliced the roast, not quit all the way through so it would stay together, stuffed it into a 1 qt ziplock bag, and poured the marinade in, making sure it got between the slices.  I marinated at room temp for 1 hour, then roasted as directed until the meat thermometer indicated 145 degrees. That only took 45 minutes, but I thought it was because it was sliced and/or because I was using a convection oven. However, it was a bit too rare for us, so I microwaved it for a minute for each of our plates and that fixed it. Next time I will definitely roast for the whole 60 minutes. I used only half the marinade for my 2 lb roast and that was plenty because I didn’t want any excess for sauce, and I roasted it on top of some asparagus, carrots, onions, and sweet potatoes. All very good except the sweet potatoes, which weren’t done, but probably would have been fine with the extra 15 or 20 minutes roasting time.

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe ! I recommend this too anyone. I did change a few things as per reading through other reviews which I think only made it better, I'm sure it would have been a delicious recipe regardless. I added a lot of chopped garlic, honey and used spicy steak rub or seasoning, my family is big on spicy meals, I didn't measure anything I just added it in to my liking. I also put big chopped onions on the bottom of the pork loin, and cut up some red potatoes and through them in the pan on the side with the juice. I cooked it for the hour with the foil tightly on, every 15 min basting it with the juices, then for 10 min I took the foil off and upped the temperature to 415 made the top and sides a little crispy. Such a delicious dish my family loved it, dinner was done in 5 min. I would recommend this meal for anyone, it's so easy and simple. I also only marinaded it for about 4 hrs and it was still delicious.

text:
Brilliant as is.  Do not skimp on cheap balsamic (will be too vinegary).  
The second time around I added equal measure of maple syrup - IT MADE IT EXTRAORDINARY (and took a little of the 'edge' off the vinegar bite)  I marinated for 2 hours.  Like other reviewers I put the loin on a bed of ringed onions, added a few carrots and mini potatoes (halved) around the loin (though the carrots were a little 'crunchy') and poured the marinade over it all.  I basted it twice in the latter half of the cooking with its own juices from the glass loaf dish it was in.

None
text:
I modified this recipe with what I had available. Instead of balsamic vinegar I used freshly squeezed lemon juice as I was given several ripe lemons from a relative. I used Montreal Steak Spice (my usual standby) and stirred in a tablespoon into the lemon juice,let it meld overnight in the fridge while my pork loin was defrosting. The next day I marinated the pork in the lemon juice mixture and olive oil(1:1) all day then roasted it according to the recipe. It was so juicy and flavorful!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not normally one to write a review on recipes because I usually tweak almost everything the recipe would call for. 
I have to say this is one of the best recipes I've ever followed, almost exactly as it is! 
I had a 2.5lb pork loin. I went to the store in attempt to buying the balsamic vinegar and olive oil. The store I went to didn't have balsamic vinegar, so I settled for Kraft Balsamic Vinaigrette "dressing" in with all the salad dressings. I used that, followed all of the other measurements this recipe called for, and marinated my pork loin for about 2.5 hours. 
After putting my pork loin in and basting a couple times, about half way through I thought the loin was cooking a little too quick for the time and heat called for. I reduced the heat to 325 degrees for about 20 minutes, basted it again and turned the heat back up to 350 degrees. 
I never changed the cooking time, and this loin came out absolutely PERFECT!! I made very minor changes, and I would not change a thing next time. my family loved it, and this will definitely be something we make again and again in the future!! Thank you for this recipe!!!

text:
Not sure it was necessary but I did make some minor adjustments.  I used Napa Valley Raspberry Balsamic vinegar. I marinated the pork for approximately 2 hours.  Because I love roasting root veggies with a pork loin  I  cut root vegetables so they were approximately the same size,  briefly steamed  the vegetables ( carrots, parsnips, onions, sweet potatoes, rutabaga , turnips, Yukon Gold potatoes) and tossed them with the marinade and roasted them in the pan with the pork loin. I introduced them 30 minutes before I expected the roast to be finished.
I seared 2 roasts,  (2.5 pound) at 425 degrees F for 25 minutes, then reduced the temp to 375 degrees for 1 hour. All turned out beautifully.

text:
Took a short cut the second time making. Instead of using olive oil and balsamic vinegar, I used a balsamic vinegar salad dressing. Added extra minced garlic with steak seasoning. I also followed the advice of another reviewer and covered with foil for a hour on 450, then removed the foil and cooked at 350 for another 30. Did not marinate and the meat was still incredibly moist! Very easy and delicious meal! Definitely going to be making again.

This was the third time that I have made the roast and it is delicious! The first time the kids ( all adults) came in and complained about the vinegar smell. Now they give me the high 5 for making it for them. I had to up it to a 7 pound roast for 7 people since they eat lots of it and everyone wants a bit to take home!!
I offered BBQ ribs, steak or chicken or the pork roast and it was unanimous for the roast for a birthday Party.
It is a good starter recipe I have made it as stated the first time, cut back on the oil the second time ( good move) and had some fresh herbs so added a bit of rosemary, thyme and garlic cloves to the marinade . Definitely a favorite and very easy for a party!

text:
I have never before taken the time to review but I could not believe how good this recipe is!! It's so simple and I took the advice of several others to put 2 thick sliced onions underneath because after roasting  they were heavenly to eat.  I used montreal steak seasoning by McCormick so there was no need to add any fresh garlic.  It definitely matters what quality of balsamic vinegar you use.  Others mentioned adding honey, a good balsamic  vinegar is naturally sweet and that would not be necessary.  The recipe as is, is a masterpiece. I used Stuarto's 18 year aged Balsamic vinegar from a company out of Kentucky.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a surprisingly big hit with my family. I modified according to what some other reviewers suggested for a 1.3 pound pork loin. (I only marinated for an hour but it was still delicious) I did 1/4 cup balsamic, 1/4 cup olive oil and 1/4 cup dry white wine. I added roasted garlic from the jar, and a small squirt of honey.  Also mixed in the steak seasoning before pouring the marinade into the bag with the pork. Mine took 1.5 hours cooking time.  Also baked it on a bed of onions cut into thick slices. The marinade made them delicious when all was "said and cooked." I served it with rice, which also went well with the tasty marinade.

text:
This was incredible and easy!!! Did it in my pressure cooker and it turned out perfect. Browned the meat in 2 tbsp olive oil first then added sliced onions, garlic, balsamic and the rest of the EVOO.  Set pressure cooker on meat setting for 25 min and let the pressure come down naturally. Also have done chicken this way (less time on the PC though) and it was just as delicious.

This marinade was great. I used 18 year balsamic vinegar which is very sweet and flavorful. It's not cheap but worth it. I got it at a vinegar and oil store. Your regular store likely won't have this quality.  I also used a high quality olive oil which also makes a difference but I added in the cheap olive oil as well. I took the advisee of a reviewer and added jarred fresh garlic and some green onions.  The marinade is simple and awesome. Yum. The only thing I did wrong was cook the pork a bit too long.  I used it for chicken too and loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found this recipe in the Allrecipes mag that came yesterday. I am actually halfway through the recipe but learned something to share. The recipe calls for a 1/2 cup of olive oil and to marinate 8 hours. Obviously you can't leave the pork out for 8 hours so I put it in the refrigeration. After 4 hours I went to turn it over in the bag and then realized that OLIVE OIL solidifies in the fridge. So I had to leave it out until it liquefied and then put back and fridge and do that twice more. It will not marinate the meat if the oil is hardened. In three more hours I will cook it and then I'll see how well recipe worked.
Review:

I usually try to follow recipes exactly but I hated the instruction to baste it. I used a high grade, expensive balsamic vinegar (used the entire bottle) because I new cheap ones would probably be too vinegary. I also marinaded it overnight instead of the two hours. It didn't smell like vinegar at all when I opened it and it was pretty yummy. However, I think the one hour cook time in my oven was a bit too long since I wasn't opening my oven.

I used a 3.64 lb pork roast and doubled the recipe for marinade, marinated it a full day.  Cooked it just as instructed even though it was larger roast; no need for meat thermometer just let it rest about 10 min.  Leftovers I placed in container with the cooking juice and that kept it moist.
The only cons about this is the marinade cold since the oil congeals.  While it was cooking,  my kids had to run out of the house because of the strong vinegar smell....no kidding!! It was so strong that it woke my 13 year old son up, walked around with his nose plugged.  I didn't mind the smell but it WAS pungent and lingered.  Beware for those with sensitive smell issues lol.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  My party of 5 all raved about the flavor of this recipe.  My pork loin was cut into 2 inch thick portions and i marinated them for about 5 to 6 hours.  As we are garlic fans, I did add about a teaspoon of minced garlic.  I placed thinly sliced onion on the bottom of the glass dish and covered with the marinade then placed the loin cuts on top.  You will have to shorten the cook time as these cook faster than a whole loin (about 25 min for thawed meat).  The guests raved about how good the pork was and how good the onion taste with it.   I recommend adding the onion for an over-the-top dish.

I had to modify for what I have on hand,  but the flavor was excellent.  I mixed half olive oil and half grapeseed oil with red wine vinegar instead of balsamic, and blacken seasoning instead of steak dressing.  I used a small whole clove of crushed garlic in the marinade as well. After marinading, I coated the pork in blacken seasoning as well and put in a covered glass baking dish for 60 minutes,  which I think was 5 minutes too long for my cut.  At 50 minutes, i added chunks bell peppers and onions to the dish and removed the cover.  Fortunately,  the sauce saved me from dried pork by slicing and soaking in the pan just before serving,  and the flavor was excellent.  Thanks for a great recipe!

Pretty  good and simple.
First off, if you did not follow the recipe what is the point of your review? If you made it and make it again with adjustments the second time fine, just say so.
Quality ingredients are essential if you want this to work. A good aged basalmic and a high quality EVO make all the difference. Watch your temp and do not over cook!  This was truly delish. Brussels or an herb roasted potatoes work well as a side.
That said, I will probably try little rosemary or herb de Provence  to add an herbal note and balance the basalmic as a personal preference next time.
Thank you for a simple classic.

text:
I don't mean to sound dramatic, I will eat any food you put in front of me.   But this was honestly one of the most horrible things I have ever eaten in my life.  I wish I could give it negative stars.  I love trying new things.  We often have pork loin and pork chops cooked all different ways.  I was looking for something new and based on the reviews I HAD to try this.  I used a decent quality grocery store bought balsamic vinegar (3rd best rating on Amazon).    I followed the recipe to a T and let it marinade over night.  It was practically inedible and as I said I most definitely am NOT a picky eater.   Oddly enough, I am not much of a vegetable eater.   But I made this pork loin along with a roasted vegetable recipe I found on this site that also required the same balsamic vinegar.  They were probably the best tasting vegetables I have ever eaten.    I loved them!  Will probably make them on a weekly basis.   So I don't believe it was the vinegar that made this dish so bad.  Would not recommend to my worst enemy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined this recipe with the roasted  pork butt roast with vegetables recipe.  I made the marinade and rubbed it all over the pork butt (@4-5 lbs) and let it sit for about an hour.  I also made slits in the roast and inserted garlic cloves.  I places it in my slow cooked and sliced a whole onion on top, and cooked it on high for about 6 - 7 hours.  I used a combination of chicken broth and water to fill the slow cooker about two thirds full.  After four hours I added cubed potatoes and carrots.  As it cooked, I tasted the juice and added a bit of seasoned salt and pepper.  The meat was very tender, tasty and juicy = YUM.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife and I both loved it. The only correction I have is the same as mentioned in some other comments -- it has a little too much olive oil. Next time I make it I'll use half as much oil as balsamic vinegar.
Changes I made: I didn't have steak rub on hand, but I do know how to make it so I made my own from a little salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, Herbs de Provence, cumin, and smoked paprika. I also added a couple of teaspoons of soy sauce. 
And by the way I didn't notice the excessive vinegar smell mentioned by others. It was an excellent recipe.
UPDATE: I take back the comment about too much olive oil. I saw a video about this recipe after my critique and realized that the point is to make an emulsion by gradually stirring the olive oil into the vinegar. In an emulsion the oil is not so visible, and a 50/50 ratio of vinegar to oil is about right. So my amended criticism is that the recipe directions should be clear that you're making an emulsion. Also, emulsions generally require an emulsifier such as Dijon mustard, so that would be a good addition to the recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-01-08T23:48:39.11

text:
I made it a little differently, leaning toward Italian/mediterranean : I skipped the seasoning, and added garlic salt, thyme, and I put half a can of diced fire-roasted tomatoes and a couple of spoonfuls of capers on top of the roast. I also chopped an onion and added it to the pan with about 1/3 cup of red wine, drizzled the whole thing with olive oil.  Amazing, and I didn't even get to marinate it that long.  Added a little water to the pan at the end to get a nice sauce out of it. Served with brown rice and roasted cauliflower. Will pair leftovers with a little pasta and roasted zucchini to change it up.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My pork loin turned out to be two smaller ones that cooked faster than expected.  I should have compensated for that, but the pork was still tender and very tasty.  We love balsamic vinegar and make our own reductions, which I used for this recipe.  That may have made it a tad more tart than the regular.  

I reduced the juices while the loin rested and added a little half and half to cut back on the acidity.  That wasn't the ideal - the cream separated - but it still made for a nice sauce that everyone enjoyed.  The onions and potatoes I added were very good, as well.  

For us, a sauce finish that is more able to offset the acidity will be the key to an even more popular outcome.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-11-08T21:59:14.35

None
text:
Kept the marinade ingredients as written. But I used pork tenderloins, butterflied them, pounded a bit for even thickness. Marinated them for 1/2 a day. Fired up the grill, direct medium, and grilled them 7 minutes on each side. Let them rest for 5 minutes before slicing to serve. Boiled the marinade for a minute or two and drizzled it on the slices before serving. High praise from hubs! Moist, tender, delicious!

text:
Soooooo good!  Even after I had unexpected visitors and had to let it sit in the oven, this roast was so moist!!!  The balsamic vinegar was the key to great taste! Made this twice.  First time, followed the recipe exactly and husband and I loved it (that's what I rated as 5 star!).  Second time, used three large onions as a base, mixed with 1/4 c. brown sugar and 1/4 c dry red wine.   Added some lemon pepper, Vegeta seasoning and a T. of Worcestershire sauce. Placed the pork right on top and placed it into the oven.  Dam!  Even better!   Couldn't help playing with the basic recipe, but without my additions the pork was fabulous!  "Try it, you'll like it!"

text:
Having read the reviews and knowing I didn't have a high quality  balsamic on hand,  I decreased the quantity  to 1/4 cup and added some honey.   Used Montreal  Steak Seasoning  and left it to marinade  almost  24 hours .  So moist and yummy!   Threw some Yukon potatoes,  carrots and yellow  onion on the bottom of my covered roasting dish and left those in the oven after I took the pork  out to rest.  Used a meat thermometer  and mine took longer to cook - most likely due to thickness  of my pork and variations  in oven temperature.   Will definitely make  again!

text:
This recipe was so helpful and a lifesaver on a busy evening.  We decided to do an impromptu trip to the zoo and I would miss the whole "making supper" time slot.  I followed this recipe and after looking at reviews and thinking of my kids preferences I added 1/4 cup honey and halved the vinegar.  Marinated for about 30 minutes then threw it in the crock pot with a frozen package of stew vegetables (including potatoes) on high for four and a half hours.  When we got back from the zoo supper was ready and ALL my kids ate it up and asked for more.  That never happens!  Couldn't have been more pleased.

text:
I've made this several times in the past. If you find the vinegar smell is to strong, you haven't used a well aged Balsamic vinegar. There is an enormous difference between aged Balsamic vinegar and standard Balsamic vinegar. Brand makes a big difference also.

userID:
647771
Display Name:
OGBURN715

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my favorite go to dinners, even on a weeknight. I do not marinate the meat at all. I add in some dried, minced onion to the sauce and pour it over the pork loin. I turn the oven temp up some and let it cook for 30 minutes. Turn the pork loin over so both sides get the yummy flavor and cook for 30 more minutes. Then check it with a meat thermometer and go from there. When cooking this dish, I think it is important to pay attention to whether your meat cut is pork tenderloin versus a pork loin or roast. A pork tenderloin usually comes packaged as two tenderloins in one package. Get one that is not injected with brine or other seasonings. If you buy a pork loin, it's usually one, wide piece of meat in the package and will take longer than a hour to cook. Very good dish.

Made EXACTLY as written.  Excellent!  Bravo!  Yummmmmmm (Angels singing).  I prepared the recipe as stated but I cut my roast in half and placed both halves in my Food Saver ® Quick Marinator (2 cycles). Then I placed it in a 350° oven (in a GLASS roasting pan) for just over an hour. My instant-read thermometer registered 150°.  Perfect! I took it out of the oven and loosely tented with foil while I finished the mashed potatoes and Chef John’s Five-Spice Carrots.  Save left overs (if any) to make Chinese Spicy Hot and Sour Soup by MARBALET.   Thank you, Melissa S.! (and Chef John!

text:
Easy & delicious! Added 3 garlic cloves to marinade and instead of steak seasoning (which I did not have on hand) just did a combo of favorite dried herbs along with some paprika. Also added big onion rings, celery & carrots along with baby potatoes. We put it all into the roasting pan & poured marinade over everything, added 1/2 cup of chicken stock and refrigerated it for 2 hours before roasting. Will probably make this a holiday meal it was so easy!

text:
We absolutely loved this. The pork was fork tender and the flavour was amazing. I had a very small roast,  just over one  pound, so I halved the recipe. Because of the small size the vinegar didn't caramelize so I poured the drippings in a small pot and added a little red wine and let that reduce while the pork was resting. I seldom make a recipe twice but I can't wait to make this one again. Like so many others have said, a good quality balsamic vinegar is a must. I used http://allrecipes.com/recipe/242012/steak-dry-rub/ for the seasoning rub.

city:

text:
This is fantastic!  The whole family loved it (including two 6-year olds and an extremely finicky husband).  We didn't have any steak seasoning, so I quickly made Johnny's Spice Rub from this site- fantastic by the way.  
We reserved 1/2 cup of the marinade to be used as a sauce.
We roasted the pork on a bed of quartered onions and surrounded the pork with broccoli florets, then poured the marinade on top.  
After about 35 minutes, our roast was already cooked (a little pink in the middle).  We served the pork and veggies with the au jus and drizzled the reserved marinade on top.  
Thank you for sharing this quick and easy and delicious recipe!  We will definitely be making this again.

userID:
16525623
Display Name:
Redcaddy97
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love pork loin.  I find it to be very versatile as well as economical.  It is very lean, so the right recipe can make or break it.  We generally buy a whole loin and cut it to suit for roasts, chops, etc.  With a piece cut for "roast", I generally smoke it or make a pork pot roast on top of the stove.  

I really took a chance on this!  Not only do I generally not make oven roasts, I also tried out the oven in our new 5th wheel for the first time with this recipe.  I had no idea how true the oven temp would be and did not have a thermometer with which I could test the "trueness" of the temp of the new oven.
I followed the marinade recipe exactly using "better" quality balsamic and olive oil.  Marinated a 3 lb. roast for about 8 hours.  For the "steak seasoning" I opted for Butt Rub.  I think next time I'll use Montreal Steak just because I think that the difference in seasoning taste will be better.  Actually, plain old salt, pepper and garlic would be great.

I left the fat cap on the pork.  The recipe did not address this, but some recipes specify that you trim the fat off.  Leaving it on helps keep the roast moist and adds flavor.  It took about 2 hours for the 3 lb. roast to register 145 degrees with a meat thermometer.   While it was cooking, I thought it smelled wonderful, but hubby came in from outside and said "it smells funky in here".   Well, so do broccoli and Brussels sprouts when they are cooking and they taste great!  Balsamic is balsamic!  It DOES have a dist
Review:

text:
Based on reading the reviews, I added garlic and reduced the Olive oil to 1/4 cup. It was the juiciest, tastiest pork I have had in a longtime, and better than any pork I personally have ever made. It is a keeper. Super easy, yet nice enough for company. I wondered if those who complained about the smell of vinegar was using Balsamic Vinegar versus regular vinegar or substituted a apple cider vinegar or red wine vinegar. Good balsamic vinegar is mild and smooth and taste great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for my family and it was really good, but I will make changes the next time to improve the over all result. I cooked a 3 lb pork loin roast and increased the cooking time accordingly. I used the recommended marinade portions for the 2 lb roast and it was more than adequate. I marinated the roast for 4 hours before cooking. My only addition this time was 2 cloves of minced garlic.  While the flavor was really nice, and the roast was moist, the marinade never became thick and truly sauce like. It was also much too greasy. I added quartered new potatoes 1/2 way through cooking and when I pulled the roast out to rest for 10 minutes I continued cooking the potatoes and increased the temperature to 450. 
Next time I plan to add the garlic again, add a tablespoon of honey and cut the olive oil in half.  I will probably marinate overnight and cook on top of a layer of sliced vidallia onions as other reviewers suggested.
Quick and easy. I'm glad to have this recipe!

I made the recipe exactly as written and it was excellent - moist and full of flavor. I used a good quality balsamic vinegar and it wasn't vinegary at all. I only marinated the pork loin for a little over an hour, but imagine that marinating it longer would only make it even more flavorful. I will definitely make this again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this dish. It has been my go-to potluck showstopper ever since I found the recipe on allrecipes.com. So simple in its ingredients yet so rich in flavor once done. The secret is in the slow cooking over low heat -- 350F. The right balance of balsamic vinegar  -- and yes, invest on the milder, pricey kind -- and olive oil to your liking, will do the trick. The first time you try it, just do 2/3 of vinegar. I use 2 lbs of pork loin and follow this measurement. I also replaced the steak rub with the McCormick burger onion rub and a bit of thyme. I garnish with slices of pear and then drizzle with the juice from the roast. Marvelous.

text:
Nice and simple, but I modded it.  I can't make myself cook with expensive salad-quality balsamic or olive oil, and don't use steak mixes.   I mixed quarter cups of cheap balsamic and OO, added splash of soy sauce,  Heinz ketchup, some red chili and cayenne flakes to offset the vinegar.   Lined a baking tin with foil to avoid cleanup.  Good.

I made this exactly like the recipe called for with one exception--I had Apple basalmic vinegar -which is what I used.  Everything else was the same. I used WildTree Rancher Steakrub and marinated it for about four hours after which baked it in my cast iron Dutch oven for approximately 50 minutes. I took it from the oven and allowed it to set for approximately seven minutes and then lifted the lid. It. Was. Amazing!  Perfectly moist. Perfectly tender. Perfect! I have never had a pork tenderloin turn out so well-so moist and this will be my new "go to"recipe.

text:
I have never written a review on here but this recipe deserves the highest praise! I've been making it for 3 years - sometimes as often as once a week. My family loves it and its soo easy! I throw it in the marinade in the morning and then have an easy dinner. 

My only modifications are that I use a Fig Balsamic Vinegar instead of regular and that the time is less if you cook two smaller roasts (like the two-pack from Costco) at once. I use a meat thermometer but it usually takes around a 30-40 minutes.

This one is definitely worth a try!

text:
We made this & it's ok, the balsamic flavor is there, it's not overbearing but I feel it needed some other spices in general for more flavor. As for temp of 145, we used a probe & taking the meat out @ 135deg is recommended & definitely allowing to rest for the 10 min as stated as ours rose 15 deg AFTER removing from our toaster oven that we used & worked quite well. We marinated for 2 days & slightly tenderized the pork loin, which I would do again because it seems larger pieces of meat need this in order to absorb the marinate.

Simple, succulent sassy solution to the question, "What am I gonna do with this pork loin in my fridge that's about to expire?"  Minutes to make the marinade, bag it, marinate it, into the oven for an our and voila... best of all its tender, moist, sweet and a major hit with the fam.  Definitely worth the upgrade from a last minute desperation effort to a planned mainstay in our pork repertoire.  I will say that the better the basalmic and the more time in marinade the sweeter the smiles. Oh, I used Webbers Steak and chop rub... Yumm!

userID:
1629120
Display Name:
Diane V
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/547903.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe. It's very easy to make. Marinate pork tenderloins for 1-2 days. Sear the loins before baking. Bake at 350F for 40-45 minutes to reach internal temp of 150 degrees.  Instead of steak seasoning in the marinade I mix up salt, black pepper and Lawrys Seasoned Salt. NOTE: Use 1/4-1/3 cup balsamic (1/2 cup is too much). Add worcestershire to marinade. Serve with rice or potatoes, green beans, cooked carrots and sautéed apples.

text:
I LOVE this recipe and have made it many times!  Super easy and definitely would serve this at a dinner party.  This recipe is perfect as is but sometimes I add a couple cloves of minced garlic, some rosemary, and some honey to the marinade. I serve it with garlic mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli.  One tip I have is to let your pork loin rest on the counter in the marinade for a couple of hours before roasting.  Shortens roasting time and allows for more even cooking.

userID:
14383764
Display Name:
Jeff_Paleo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a little annoyed at first since the steak rub brand or composition was not specified. I generally ignore recipes that call for ambiguous ingredients. However, one reviewer stated that s/he used Adobo spice mix (thanks to whomever that was). I happened to have that on-hand and used the same along with minced garlic which was also recommended by the same person (I used five cloves). I used an good quality aged balsamic and marinated overnight. I also substituted avocado oil for the olive oil just because I worry about olive oil breaking down in the heat. We cooked it in our little Hamilton Beach countertop oven on 250 degrees convection setting until internal temp of 145 degrees. And actually olive oil would not have been a problem at 250, but I pretty much always cook with "refined", high heat avocado oil. Personally I would not use olive oil at 350 though. The roast came out perfect; extremely tender and very tasty but it took at least 2 hours for a 3 1/4 lb roast. I'm glad I didn't blow off this recipe. I agree with others who said to avoid using a cheap balsamic if possible because it will be more tart and probably less flavorful. But who knows; I have not tried the cheaper stuff which I do also buy as I cannot afford the good stuff for every use.
Review:

5
dateLastModified:

userID:
3884213
Display Name:
Kimberly Hillenbrand
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would give this recipe six stars if I could, it is honestly one of the best recipes I have gotten off this site (Worlds best lasagna would the the other).  The only thing I changed was to add a couple tablespoons of honey to the marinade. My husband wanted to grill it, but I am so glad I decided to bake it in the oven instead. Two main recommendations for making this: if you are an onion fan, you will definitely want to put sliced onions in the pan while baking. The are soooo good served over the pork slices. Second, serve this with some type of bread or dinner rolls,  my family loved dipping the bread in the juices.....so incredibly good.  I baked a two lb. pork loin, half the time cover with foil, half without.  At the one hour point my thermometer read 120 so I kicked the Temp up to 375, but be careful, it cooked quickly at that point, getting up to almost 160 before I took it out (wanted to get it out at 145). It still was tender and not overcooked. This will probably be the only way I cook pork loin from now on, so simple with restaurant quality results.

text:
This turned out pretty well. I didn't have steak seasoning, so used garlic powder, chili powder, salt, and pepper. I poked the roast with serving fork all around so the marinade could get into the meat and marinated for about 3 hours. Cooked at 350F but it wasn't quite done at an hour, about 125 degrees F, so I let it go for another 20 minutes or so. That got it up to about 150, so I was worried I had overdone it. But no, it was still tender and just moist. Any longer and it would have been dry. The flavor was good, with the balsamic neither overpowering nor boring.

I had 2 packages of  pork loin tips on hand and loved it more than the whole Loin that would need to be sliced. I added 3 Tbs. Honey  and 8 cloves of Chopped Garlic  to the marnInade, reseasoned the tips before putting into the oven with a tent for 45 mins on 350 and removed the tent and cooked another 12 mins on 450 to get that amazing color caramelized flavor.... It was butter soft and the most amazing piece of pork I've  ever made!! TY for all the  great tips!! :)

This is the second time I make this and I love it.  This time I marinated overnight and put in the oven at 350 degrees along with new potatoes and baby carrots all in the same pan covered with aluminium foil. text:
This was great, and so easy! I added a little garlic and dijon mustard to the marinade to help emulsify it and add some flavor. I also used Pomegranate balsamic vinegar because I happened to have some. I roasted it in my convection toaster oven on 350 for about 55 minutes, until the temp read 140 (really you don't need to cook it to 160!) and it was perfect. We loved the sauce!

text:
Wow. This is a delicious roast that is so easy. I added about 2 tbsp of honey as someone else suggested. I really like to combination of balsamic vinegar and honey but I think this would be good without that addition. I marinaded this over night and when I put it into the pan to cook I threw in some potatoes and carrots cut up. I also poured all the marinade over top of everything and stirred the veggies so that they would be covered in marinade. The secret to a good pork loin is a meat thermometer. Cook it to 160* and let it rest a few minutes before slicing it.

text:
After reading from some that this recipe had too much vinegar flavor, I used 1/4 cup balsamic and 1/4 cup rice vinegar. It seemed a little mild. I would have preferred the 1/2 cup balsamic. Also, I added 1-2 cloves minced garlic and 1/3 cup chopped green onions. This recipe is definitely repeatable with those changes.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1127392.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished this meal. Family liked it a lot. Won't say it lived up to my week-in-planning high expectation, but it was pretty good.  Followed basic recipe exactly-but cooked longer (>90 min) for large cubed sweet potato I added to get done-plus from other reviews, I added 1 bunch of chopped green onions, 3 cloves of minced garlic and 1/8 cup of honey to my corningware dish. I do caution against using McCormick's SPICY Montreal as it had quite a distracting bite (especially harsh flavor on the potato), even though I only used 1 TBSP of it with 1 TBSP of Weber's Chicago Steak mix. Pork was somewhat tender after 9 hour marination, and even though cooked uncovered the whole time, I had plenty of liquid left in dish to spoon over sliced pork and potato, both. Meat wasn't moist, nor quite dry, but I probably overcooked it...? Silly amateur! I will try this again according to a lot of other reviews and set a bed of sliced onion under the loin, maybe add mushroom, too. Definitely will not use SPICY seasoning again! Will disclose if it turns up a winner.

text:
This was absolutely the most amazing pork loin roast I have ever made. My family devoured it and they are not fans of balsamic vinegar at all. I do think having a good quality balsamic must make a difference because ours did not taste like vinegar at all. I didn't change a single thing in this recipe. I will definitely be making this again! Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. It is definitely a keeper!!

Disappointed :(  I was initially very excited to try this recipe since I like the ingredients and the reviews were favorable overall. Given my success with other recipes on this site, I assumed it would be another hit. I was mistaken. The pork was fair at best. I made no changes to the recipe and made it exactly as instructed. In our family I always ask every time I try a recipe, "Hey guys,is this a do-againer?" it was suspiciously quiet after I popped the question. Finally my husband sheepishly said, "I like your other pork recipes better." I really wanted to like this recipe since it was easy and required few ingredients but it was nothing more than ordinary in the end.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a simple and delicious way to prepare pork.  Our pork loin was just under 4lbs, so it took a bit longer than the recipe states to cook.  It also mentions a temp of 145, but when I pulled the pork out at that meat temp, it was still a bit pink.  At about 165/170 degree was perfect for us.  Meat was still very tender and juicy.  The marinade was so flavorful and really added an extra "zing" to the pork.  We marinated it for just about 3 hours, I'm sure it only gets better the longer it sits. Paired it with some roasted asparagus, was a wonderful dinner!

This was amazing! I was confused on if you're supposed to cook it in the marinade or drain it. I only marinated for 1 1/2 hours and then drained out most of the liquid. It took 1 hr 45 min for my 2 lb pork roast so next time start earlier.  I did bast it 2 times and it was delicious.  My 2 year old and 8 year old ate every bite of their meat as well. I only found it necessary to use half the required liquid listed because I was scared of it being too much vinegar or too oily.

Easy, easy, easy!! This makes a wonderful roasted pork loin! I love it every time I make it, and the house always smells divine when its cooking. I have used McCormick Montreal steak seasoning and also rendezvous restaurant dry rub (from memphis, TN) as the steak seasoning in this recipe. Both are delicious! It's great for company, just slice up and serve!!

text:
I just finished our meal with this recipe and it was a hit!  I had a 4lb pork loin so I doubled everything.  It marinated 20 hours.  The sliced onion bed for the roast should have been doubled since those caramelized onions were divine on top of the sliced pork.  I did not baste the meat while it roasted.  The only problem I had was the cooking temperature - it roasted about 2 hours to get to 145 on my instant read thermometer.  I tented foil over the roast but after 30 min. it only rose to 153.  The confusion over whether the roast was done or not is the only reason I gave it 4 stars.  We will enjoy the leftovers too.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe and way too easy.  There is no vinegar smell as another reviewer said; balsamic vinegar is different than regular vinegar so make sure you purchase the right item (they can't be substituted for each other).  I used southwestern seasoning I had handy instead of purchasing steak seasoning and it was perfect.  I put the ingredients in a gallon sized zip locked bag and shook them up really well as the oil will want to separate from the other ingredients   I then placed the pork loin in the bag, put it in the dish I was going to cook in and put it in the fridge.  I rotated the loin every few hours until I went to bed.  The next day I emptied everything into the dish and baked.  I didn't baste the meat at all once it was in the oven and it came out great.  Even my picky 7 yr old nephew had seconds.  I will definitely be using this recipe again and again.  It's a winner.

text:
Very tasty. I think the number one problem with most of the critics is inept altitude adjustment and faulty butchers. I graduated from culinary institute of toronto and the cuts of meat we produced were choice.  Its a  shoot when you're out nickle and diming joe schmo for a pork loin, but even for you there is some hope.  When you get home from grocery, let the loin breathe(yes out of the package) for about 5 hours outside to rekindle the juices.  Then proceed with the recipe.

text:
I was disappointed in how tough the roast turned.  The balsamic marinade is pretty tasty, so I cut up the meat into chunks and let it swim in the marinade.  That seemed to help, but cooking the roast to 145 degrees was too long for this roast.  It didn't have any pink in the middle at all.  For me, I like a little pin, so it stays tender.  I don't know what the problems were.  Maybe I didn't let it sit at room temperature long enough.  Maybe it's because I forgot to  baste it while it was cooking.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2013-03-29T12:45:22.237
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
9441875
Display Name:
holly
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
116
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/999297.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe sounded too good/easy to be true-but decided to go for it because I had a pork loin and couldn't think of anything else to do-plus I had all (mostly) ingredients on hand. It was quite possibly the BEST pork loin we have ever eaten! Perfectly cooked, very moist and juicy, and flavorful. Definitely a keeper in this house. I even went and bought another loin to have on hand as I have a feeling will make again sooner rather than later. 
Now for the variations I used after reading many reviews...
We don't use steak seasoning but did have some Cajun Tiger Dust which I used in place of - it's basically same as steak seasoning but with a kick. I added a little honey (~1/4 cup) to the marinade. After reading up on marinating faster (an oxymoron but it worked!) , I "poked" the loin in several places with a paring knife as I needed to get on the table. Because I wanted to make it a meal, I thick sliced and onion (med size), cubed 4-5 red potatoes and sliced ~ 2cups of baby carrots in half, tossed all with the marinade, nestled the loin with the veggies and cooked to 150*. Wanted to put veggies back in oven for ~15 minutes but had hungry boys standing with plates ready to devour so turned out more like 10. Sliced the pork about 1/2" thick and served over a mound of the veggies. The sauce was phenomenal (we LOVE balsamic)-boys kept dipping forkfuls in dish for more "gravy!" One of the best meals I have enjoyed in a while and so simple.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-03-28T23:06:17.08
helpfulCount:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night for my husband and I. I followed the directions except I tweeked it a bit for my taste: 1) I decreased the balsamic vinegar and olive oil to 1/3 cup each; 2) I added 1/4 cup of red wine(zinfandel is what I had on hand; 3) I added about 1/4 cup of water to the resealable bag to get out all the seasonings and oil and squeezed the bag really well into my crockpot; 4) I placed everything in my crockpot and cooked on low for about 8-9 hours. I also microwaved (1) white yukon gold potato and (1) sweet potato(both sliced in quarters) and placed in the crockpot 1 hour before the roast was done.
This was probably the best pork loin roast I have had in a long time. It was moist and flavorful and did not have a strong balsamic vinegar taste. My husband is a picky eater and he really enjoyed it. I will definitely make this again.

text:
I've made this several times, and each time it was amazing. I don't change the recipe, but I do put a little of the marinade on the bottom of the baking dish before I drop the pork loin in to keep it from burning/sticking to the pan. I also lightly dust it with coarse ground pepper for a bit of a kick. It's so good, and SO easy to make. If you have the time, marinade it overnight, the difference in the taste is astounding.

text:
I had a smaller roast, 1.2 lb.  but I used the same amounts for the marinade because we like lots of sauce.  Marinated only two hours, added a sliced onion to the bottom of the pan, placed the roast on top and poured the marinade over all of it.  Baked at 350 degrees until the temp was 150 degrees. Let it rest for a few minutes.  Wow!  So delicious.  Very tender and the onions were a bonus.  The vinegar I used was  from Williams Sonoma and I used a garlic infused olive oil.  Good balsamic is the secret I think.  Will make this again.

Display Name:
laura_lou

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a fantastic recipe: super simple and easy to throw together before work, and delicious when we got home. After reading the reviews, I decided to add a tablespoon or two of honey to the marinade to avoid the vinegar smell, but I really think the trick is to use good balsamic, as the best balsamic vinegar is sweet enough to eat. Looking for terms like "barrel aged" and shaking the bottle to see how thick it is (it should be almost syrupy if it's a higher quality vinegar) is a good way to buy balsamic. You don't have to go for the most expensive kinds! I used DennyMike's Pixie Dust barbeque rub instead of steak seasoning, and it gave it the most amazing flavor. We poured the rest of the cooked marinade over asparagus because it was so good! Definitely will use again, although it's important to adjust your cooking time if you (like me) bought a smaller pork loin, as the original poster used a 2 lb. loin and I almost overcooked it.

userID:
3480930
Display Name:
June Buchanan Evers
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1408715.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had a boring pork loin roast and a bunch of veggies to get rid of and felt very uninspired until I saw this recipe.  I pretty much followed it but did make a few changes.  I lined my Pampered Chef cookie bar pan with heavy duty foil and sprayed with cooking spray.  I cut up 3 sm. onions, a green pepper and a red pepper, a head of broccoli and a couple handfuls of baby carrots.  I spread them on the entire sheet and drizzled with oil and sprinkled with 2 tsp. from a Good Seasons dry dressing packet.  I roasted the veggies at 450 for 30 minutes.  Meanwhile I marinated the pork in 1/3 c. balsamic oil, 1/2 c. oil, the rest of the dry dressing packet and a generous shaking of granulated garlic while the veggies were roasting.  I then made room for the pork along side the veggies and poured the marinade, which had thickened up, over the pork and some of the veggies. I also poured about a cup and a half of chicken broth over the veggies to keep them from getting dried out.  I put an oven probe into the center (the kind that you leave in while roasting) and waited for the temp to get to 150.  45-minutes later I have an amazing looking and tasting pork roast and the veggies are perfect!  I'm sorry I changed things up but this recipe did offer great inspiration and a good starting point.  I served it all with mashed potatoes.  A Riesling goes well with this, too.

text:
If the smell of Balsamic vinegar is strong, then you are using an inexpensive brand.  Balsamic vinegar has to be aged to acquire a mild yet yummy taste and smell.  A very good one is DeLallo Aged Balsamic Vinegar.  It costs a couple dollars more, but it is soooo good.  Rather than throw away a few dollars, enjoy something for a couple dollars more.

text:
This recipe is great. Although it uses a heavy dose of balsamic, the finished product is not noticeabley vinegary. I didn't alter this much, just added a clove of garlic to the marinade. Marinaded for 2 hours in the fridge, then put the loin and the marinade in a glass pie plate (9x13 was MIA). My meat thermometer was also nowhere to be found, but I baked at 350 for 40 minutes and it was perfectly tender. My roast was 1.3 pounds.

Will definitely make this again. So easy and very tasty.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last night and it was awesome!  I had to make changes to accommodate for what I had in the house and it turned out super tender and full of flavor!! 

I used 2 tablespoons Montreal Steak Seasoning, 1/2 cup creamy balsamic vinaigrette (Ken's Dressing brand), 1/3 cup olive oil, 1 tablespoon minced garlic and a pork loin cut in half.  I put the meat in the marinated and covered all sides, then took out and browned in a hot pan and put back in marinade for two hours.  I cooked for 40 minutes at 350 degrees then took out, cut into pork chop size slices and browned in hot pan until cooked through.

This is a very good recipe.  I can't give it 5 stars though as I felt it was somewhat bland.  To turn it up a notch, I added fresh herbs I had to the marinade: garlic, basil, parsley, oregano, and thyme.  Then also decreased the oil and vinegar to 1/3 cup.  Be careful not to overbake it or it becomes dry.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first review, and this recipe was worth it.  I've been trying to find a way to cook a pork loin that all our children would eat because it's less per pound than even hamburger.  This is it.  I have to say, I made some changes due to what I had on hand.  Used Worchestershire sauce, a little paprika, salt, & pepper instead of the steak seasoning.  Only had a touch of balsamic left, so I used cider vinegar & honey.  And sorry, I never marinaded it, I just popped it right in the oven.  Yes, it has a funky vinegar smell while cooking (depending on your sense of smell).  Ignore it and move on to slicing!  All 6 children (ages 6-15) had 2nds!  My picky eater, my "I don't like that kind of meat." child, and my "only a small piece" child all had 2nds & wanted to scoop up the sauce in the bottom of the pan to drizzle over their rice & meat.  I didn't have time to make a gravy, so the kids just scooped the cooked marinade from the bottom of the pan.  Husband liked it, too. Thanks Melissa for an easy and flexible recipe!

text:
I couldn't give this 5 stars yet because I used a pork tenderloin. The closest thing I had on hand to the steak seasoning was mesquite seasoning, which worked really well. I drizzled the pork loin with honey right before putting it into the oven. I left the tenderloin in the oven a bit too long, i tried to guess since it was slightly over 3 lbs and in 2 pieces, but it still turned out delicious. I used very high quality balsamic vinegar and olive oil. The resulting pan drippings made a fabulous gravy that was slightly tart, which made up for the dryness. My son had leftovers without the gravy and said it was perfect the way it was.

userID:
2257362
Display Name:
MISSYPIE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
170
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After the 6th week in a row of making this for Sunday dinner, I felt obligated to review this as AMAZING.  My hubby demands it, my 3 and 1 year old both love it.  It is a sophisticated pork dish that both adults and kids will appreciate, not for those who enjoy a sugary or bottled BBQ/french dressing pork dishes.  This tastes like restaurant food.  I make it in the crockpot using 3.5-4 pounds of lean pork loin, double the sauce, set on high for 2 hours then low for 2-3 more.  I add dried garlic, and a vegetable of choice for the week, either three cubed sweet or regular potatoes and a chopped onion, or even peppers.  anything goes with this.  I have made it once in oven and it turns out great as well, I just appreciate the crockpot with the liner for ease on the weekend, plus it does come out a little more "shredded" or "pulled" in the crock.  Also, I have a very LARGE crock so I can cook a lot.  We eat half the meat on day one with the veggies from pot, and the remaining meat and sauce is heated the next day in a saucepan on the stove top and served over Alton Brown's Baked Brown Rice.  We are eating this 2 nights a week, literally.  Also, for any of you Clean Eaters, this is a pretty basic ingredient list, great for those times when you need a reasonably clean meal for people who don't eat clean.  THANKS, MELISSA S!!!!!!

country:
None
text:
We didn't find this particularly flavorful but that might have changed if I'd had 24 hours to marinate it.  That said, it still marinated for over 3 hours before cooking.  I cooked it until 145 degrees, as the recipe indicated, but even with carry over cooking I still had to put it back in the oven- it was still too pink in the center and the juices weren't running clear.  I had hoped to be able to make a sauce with the pan juices but the balsamic had mostly dried up and burned and all that was left in the pan was an oil bath.  I  might make this again but will use far less oil and I would marinate longer.

My family doesn't like pork much but I like some variety in our menus!  I used this recipe & I will definitely keep it!  They loved it and.  It doesn't need to be marinated for too long to get the great taste.  I marinated it for 3 hours and it was just right.  I think over night would be too strong.  I used the leftovers in a stir fry and it was yummy both ways!

text:
This is an awesome recipe!! I've made this twice for parties and it was a huge hit both times. I pretty much followed the recipe as given the only thing I added was 2 tablespoons of chopped garlic and I marinated this for 48 hours and it produced the most tender juicy pork loin that I've ever had. Definitely use a good quality Balsamic vinegar, I used a low cost one the first time and it was good, but used a high quality Balsamic the last time and it truly does make a huge difference! I'll be making this many more times for sure!
